reviewText:
This game has some advantages and disadvantages to a similar title with a lot more polish: Endless Legends. I thought I'd compare the two.

Advantages to Fallen Enchantress:

+ You can rotate the map, which is nice in tactical mode (during battles).

+ The quests you get have less variety compared to Endless Legends, but in Enchantress they invariably involve combat of some kind, which is good for people who like combat. Also, there are sometimes branching paths in quests, a concept pretty much unheard of in Endless.

+ The fantasy setting is great if you like that kind of thing. I do, and it's the biggest reason to like this game imho. Endless Legends has this strange cyberpunk/fantasy hybrid thing going on which rarely makes sense.

+ Huge customization. You can create your empire or kingdom from scratch, rather than the civ standby of picking from the list of pre-made leaders. You can pick and choose bonuses (and penalties) to fit your playstyle, as well as having full control over the color palette that will appear on your units and cities. While equipping units is done in Endless Legends as well as Fallen Enchantress, Enchantress has a tad more variety in the early game and also has the advantage that your units change their appearance with their gear, a feature Endless lacks.

Disadvantages to Fallen Enchantress:

- The maps. City placement is restricted to fixed locations, and battles play out in an instanced flat plane with no variety. In Endless Legends you can build wherever the hell you want like a normal civ game and when two stacks of units fight, the overall game pauses and the units spread out into the surrounding tiles, to duke it out for six rounds. This means that units are affected by terrain and elevation, and it also means battles can be stalemates or attrition fights rather than the forced fight to the death in Enchantress.

- Diplomacy is wonkier than Civ. When I played, I regularly had enemy civs offer me money out of the blue. There's a demand tribute button on the diplomacy screen, but there's also a give tribute button which will automagically give the recieving player 10% of your gold income for 30 turns. If your arbitrary point total (if you played any recent Civ game you know what I mean) is above a certain point, your opponents will shower you in gifst in the hope that you attack them last. It's funny at first, until you realize that ten percent of their income is almost always nothing and it's a completely hollow gesture in the first place. If you accept tribute from them, it gives the other civ a negative diplomacy moodlet becaude 'you demanded tribute from them'. Which, ironically, makes them more afraid you'll attack them and more likely to give tribute in the future. Also worth noting is treaties and trade are separate options in this game and that treaties must be picked one at a time, so you can't do things like sign borders agreements or take cities in exchange for peace. You either mutually accept peace (with a possible bribe in gold if needed), or you surrender everything and quit the game. There is no other way to end a war prematurely.

- No navy. The sea (and air) are sorely lacking in Fallen Enchantress. Any lakes you encounter (and you will) are impassible voids. This is a shame, because a heavy focus into earth magic (if you're lucky enough to randomly generate a champion unit that knows some) eventually nets you the ability to terraform the land around you. You can turn sea into land, land into settleable land or hills, hills to mountains and vice versa. The problem is that, as mentioned, terrain has no impact on combat and cities don't work neighboring tiles, so there's very little motivation to actually do this.

- The minimalistic approach. Numbers in this game are very small. You'll spend ten turns on a building that nets you +1 science per turn. Every customization option in this game, from making units to leveling champions to constructing buildings to upgrading them to using spells in or out of combat to making your empire in the first place, all of them are minimalistic tweaks. Despite all the options you have, none of it actually does much of anything. You might see a building that generates double the science that your city already produced, until you realize you built every science building available and you're only producing seven, and that building replaces another one which already increased your science output by 75% so instead of netting +7 science for your twenty turns of production, you're actually only getting +1. Your units will get damage buffs of 10 to 20 percent at a time, but that translates into 1-2 extra damage on your attack, which won't make a difference to the vast majority of enemies. Whenther they had the buff or not it'll still take the same amout of attacks, same number of turns in combat, to kill anything. The result is that the game feels very hollow, where it looks on the surface like there's a lot of replay value but there actually isn't. Seeing as replay value is the ultimate goal for a 4x game, this is a serious shortcoming.

Summary:

If you just rewatched Game of Thrones and you REALLY want to play a Civ game that uses a fantasy setting and magic and whatnot, if you want to play dress-up with your units and if you really don't care if the game is actually any good, you might as well play Fallen Enchantress. But if what you're looking for is a 4x game with any level of depth, a game that will entertain you for more than a few hours and a game where your choices have a drastic impact on the flow of the game, go for Endless Legends.

Oh, and Legends has multiplayer, for the people who care about that.

reviewText:
I've been part of the Elemental odyssey since the early days of the paid beta for War of Magic.  As we all know by now, Elementa: War of Magic arrived in a pretty bad state and never recovered from its severe design deficiencies.  Stardock, being Stardock, refused to abandon their dream of a great new 4X fantasy game and released a stand-alone expansion, Fallen Enchantress, that tried to rectify what went wrong with the first game by cutting out lots of features of the original that just didn't work, and by enhancing what was left.  When all was said and done, while Fallen Enchantress was a marked improvement over EWoM, it still struck me as a mediocre game.

When Legendary Heroes was added to my account (I was one of those who were 'comped' with two free expansions) , I was not in any rush to try it.  I mean, seeing how FE was still nothing that great, I figured LH was going to be just another incremental improvement on the base game.

I WAS WRONG!

Legendary Heroes has completely amazed me with its gameplay (especially with the recent 1.4 patch).  Finally, we have an Elemental game that lives up to the hopes and dreams we all had when Elemental was first announced!  This is now a fantastic fantasy-based 4X experience with lots of faction/hero customization options that really adds a great RPG element, as well as a smart implementation of the core 4X (explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate) gameplay dynamic.  The tactial battles, which were a bit bland before, are now fun and challenging endeavors (the tactical AI is very good!).  City building, which was also rather boring in the previous iterations of the series, has received a lot of love, amking it a quite enjoyable to watch your cities grow.  Questing has also received some nice attention, making for some interesting one-off battles.  Add in some game changing" random events (something Stardock is known for)
date: and you now have a very addictive
recommended:
very polished experienced.

Stardock has also just begun releasing DLC for the game.  While I have only purchased the Quest DLC so far - it seems to offer the most bang for the buck at the moment - I suspect we can expect a lot more that should really enhance the game even more.

Lastly
hoursPlayed: this being a proper PC game
voteText: there are some great mods already available.\n\nLong short: Legendary Heroes is a very good 4X fantasy game that is well worth your gaming dollar.  I don't think it is too much of a stretch to say that with some more DLC and/or an expansion
helpfulPercent: Legendary Heroes could well match the revered status of Stardock's sci-fi  magnum opus
votesHelpful: Galactic Civilizations II."

reviewText:
I feel FE:LH is extremely underrated and Stardock did one hell of a job here balancing and polishing FE, worth noting that it was done with the help of none other than Civ 4's lead designer.

This is technically an expansion but it should really be treated as a standalone game. Replayability in this is amazing, customization options are infinite (that includes shaping the world to your liking, creating armor for your armies and pimping out your sovereign), fun combat and just tons of other cool ♥♥♥♥ I cannot bother listing here. Depth isn't something FE is lacking, either. Diplomacy sucks donkey balls however, but at least it ain't Warlock: MotA... *shudder*

TL;DR: Very fun 4x strategy game, that is similar to MoM/AoW in terms of gameplay, with Civilization-esque building and RPG aspects like in HoMM. Don't buy the original FE, buy this instead. Also DLC's are a great addition, specifically the quest pack. Rest is OK if you're into smacking goblins with giant lollipops.

reviewText:
Take over the role of a mighty sovereign in his or her struggle to rebuild the world after the cataclysm.
Magic so powerful is at your disposal that the earth itself shatters beneath you!
You will build cities, take over wild ressources, train soldiers and mages, recruit heroes to fight alongside your sovereign, learn magic powerful enough to win the game, forge alliances, discover ancient quests and clash with your enemies in round-based battles.
The most powerful sovereign will always outshine any other unit and this is as much a strategy-game as it is a role-play-game.
Prepare your mind for this game will surely make an impact!

reviewText:
As much as I love the game concepts in FE:LH, I simply cannot recommend it because the way the developers implemented these concepts is (to me, anyway) very shallow and frustrating. It does offer a little fun, but barely enough for even the sale price of $9.99 to feel worth it (and certainly not for full price). I'll elaborate in greater detail below.

This review is based upon my time playing the game during this free-to-play weekend, though I previously played over 100 hours (not on steam) in Elemental and also tried out the free copy of the first FE Stardock gave me (but it didn't keep my interest very long at all).

Here is a list of my main frustrations:
-For a game called Legendary Heroes"
date: you barely get any heroes to play with;\n\n-Even worse
recommended: the leveling system for the heroes you do get doesn't do them any justice;\n\n-Creation of custom Sovereigns and Races sounds cool
voteText: tactical battles lack any real depth - not to mention the many other issues with them (no troop placement phase
helpfulPercent: inconsistent battle map sizes
votesHelpful: etc);\n\n-Overall
votesTotal: these frustrations result in a negative gameplay experience for me
votesFunny: to the point where even the interesting environments
commentsCount: quests to complete
column16: and wild monsters to fight just cannot keep me invested in playing. I love the concepts so very much
column17:
but their implementation kills the potential fun.

Read on for a more detailed look at these issues:

Not Enough Heroes
You can only recruit a new hero when you reach certain levels of "fame"
column18: which you get from completing quests from random locations spawned on the map. Each new level requires even more fame
column19: such that in my 12 hours of free playing I had only gotten a mere 2 heroes. This is simply unacceptable for a game called "Legendary Heroes" and it seriously undermines the RPG aspect of play. Furthermore
column20: when you unlock a new hero you are only offered a choice between 2 candidates. The first time
column22: which meant I got to choose my first hero's class when she reached level 2 (I went with Defender
column23: as my Sovereign was a Warlock); but when I finally unlocked my second choice of heroes
column25:
meaning that I was stuck with the classes already assigned to them (either another Defender or another Warlock...while I wanted to pick another class I didn't have yet). This was extremely frustrating and not at all fun.

Hero Leveling is a Disappointment
Every time a hero gains a level
column26: they get 1 point to spend on a new perk (including passive buffs and active abilities). All heroes have a few General perks available
column27: while the majority are based on their class (Defender
column29: etc). The first problem is that 1 skill point per level is not enough to give you a decent selection. Want them to unlock the next 3 spells in the type of magic they know? There goes your point. Want them to learn first aid? Their goes your point. And levels require a lot of fighting to get.\n\nLimited skill points wouldn't be so bad if the perks actually made a big difference
column30: but most of them don't. For my Defender
column31: some perks added only +5 HP (or the like)
column32: while a few offered new combat moves. Sadly
column33: the layout of the skill tree meant I needed to pick many lame perks before reaching the ones that actually sounded useful
column34: so in my 12 hours of play I never unlocked any cool ones for my heroes. I realize the devs may not want heroes to be overpowered (although there are so few of them in numbers that I feel they almost *should* be a bit OP)
column35: but you can do that by giving a level progression to the cool abilities so they start off weak and can be improved with further perks
column36: not by making it very slow and frustrating to even unlock the abilities at all. Anyway
column37:
the leveling system is very frustrating and kills the fun for me.

Custom Sovereign/Faction/Unit Creation is Shallow
Customization is one of my favorite aspects in a game
column38: in both the practical and aesthetic senses (custom ship design from Gal Civ II is a great example). This game appears to offer these features
column39: but once you dig in they are really very shallow. While there are nuances between the 3 types of custom creation
column40: all three share the same flaws: too few deign points
column41: too few design options (in particular for "weaknesses" that let you take a hit in one area to gain more design points to enhance another area)
column42: and the options they do have ultimately don't create a different feeling or play-style. This undermines not only the RPG aspect of the game
column43: but also replayability (since no faction can really get that substantively different from another). I could go much more deeply into the details and nuances of/between types of customization
column44:
but in the end I still find each kind limiting and strategically/tactically unfulfilling. It's very disappointing and undercuts my motivation for playing the game.

Poor Tactical Battles
Even by the most simple standards for a tactical battle system
column45: the game comes up short. There are few weapons to choose from for your units (on top of their already shallow customization)
column46: and the attempt to make each class of weapon have more uniqueness fails. Giving some armor penetration to spears and a knockdown chance to hammers doesn't cut it. It makes designing units really boring
column47: and tactical combat boring and repetitive as well. Ultimately
column48: it just comes down to attack and defense values to decide the outcome
column49: plus just not being stupid by letting the enemy gang up on your units (while you try to gang up on theirs). Also
column50: having a maximum army size of just 9 units really limits not only the tactical possibilities (for example
column51: I don't have enough units to
column53: shield my custom Race's unmatched archers behind a line of heavy pikemen
column54: nor does the customization system let me even make the Race of unmatched archers...)
column55: but also the sense of epic scale - you only ever fight skirmish-sized battles or send your small party against one super monster and its several minions. Anyway
column56:
the battles lose their appeal very quickly.

Conclusion
The above frustrations are what ruin my playing experience for FE:LH; hence
column57: I cannot recommend it. There are even other issues I didn't touch on (like the tech tree structure
column58: etc) that I could maybe forgive on their own
column59: but for a game called Legendary Heroes these key flaws regarding heroes/customization/battles are simply too much. Even though I will somewhat miss the match I sank 12 hours into during this free-to-play weekend
column60: it's not even worth $9.99 to me to get the game and continue playing what I started. Sadly
column61: I know that continuing it would entail more frustration with the game design than fun.\n\nIf you care more about other aspects of the game
column62: maybe you will still like it; but since many people (like me) might want to buy this because of the elements that are lacking (the promise of customization
column65: I want to call out those elements as I see them.\n"

reviewText: Fun up to a point. I really like that the soldiers in your army and the heroes that join you are all customisable, including changing their name if you want to. Having chess pieces on the strategic map that resemble the hero leading that army is a nice touch too. Ultimately, the research and city building aspect of the game lets it down though. Also, the graphics for the turn-based combat were so dated I felt like I was playing Death Knights of Krynn or something! reviewText:
OK - so I loaded up Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes... Now it wants me to make an additional account. So I am goign to leave it afk on thier request page and earn its cards without ever even looking at the game. I like steam becuase I don't have to deal with uneeded registrations and spamming my e-mail acount to bussinesses' automated advertisement bots. Enjoy Stardock!

**Edit**

-_-|
I couldnt stop myself...

... They got me to sign up with their luancher. Nuuu!!!!

Resulting game play gave me the following thoughts:

For a game with so much to offer, they missed what I feel are the basics.

Game play is generic.
Focus seems to be on the heros that you can gain and how you level them. The fighting is boring with a predictable AI and terrain that has no advantage in battle. I was so underwelmed from the fighting that I ended up hitting the automated attack button. The most action I got out of this game was hitting the End Turn button to speed up building.

No city design controll.
Perhaps this next issue won't bother you, but it irritated me to no end. You cannot place the items in your town were you would liek them to go. You just hit the develop button and then order the items you want made first.

UI is unfriendly
This section is to complain about how unfriendly the controll are in this game. Although mastery of the UI is not hard, it does not feel natural. A few more easy to use button would have made a large differnce as well as a few windows. For instance, I would have like a better way to form war parties instead of clicking on the town, then the soldier, then a blank square outside the city, and then finally repeat for each other soldier I want in the group making sure to have them join the same square outside of town. Even if it only took a couple of minutes, that is time further waisted through uneeded tedium.

My final adivce
There are better browser 4x games for free out there. I would pass on this game unless you are looking at a massive discount.

reviewText:
Do you like the Civilization game series? How about Heroes of Might and Magic?  Think of this game as their 'not the sharpest knife in the drawer' child.

Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes tries to be a game of both City-Building and Turn-Based-Combat. Unfortunately it does both of these in wonderful mediocrity.  Neither aspect of the game is fleshed out fully and this leaves you somewhat unsatisfied in both arenas.

That being said, the game is not without merit. While it's not as deep as other games, it's a decent way to scratch your TBS itch. The character models are decent and the inclusion of a fantasy setting makes the city-building interesting when starting out. The game isn't worth the asking price of $40, but if you see it on sale for $10 or less, it's probably worth your time if you're a fan of Civilization and TBS games.

reviewText: I love this game! It still has a bug every now and then but nothing that hurts the experience for me. My favorite part about it is being able to create your own factions and heroes (backstories and all) and play them. There is definitely a bit of a learning curve, but it's a fun learning curve. I've put quite a few hours in and I feel like I've barely scratched the surface of how many different strategic options there are. One of the major aspects that I love about this game is that it's not just a numbers game. Some games like this, for example Might and Magic VI, have a lot of strategic depth, but in the end it just becomes a numbers game as to who has the bigger army. This game does a really good job of balancing that out by limiting the size of each army, so you have to be more picky about what types of units make up your army, sort of like a mix between XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Might and Magic VI.

reviewText:
If you are a fan of Civiisation V, or any of the series fo CIV, then you will love this game.

Take the city screen in Civ... in this game, you see the city straight out.

Combat in Civ is quick combat... in this game, you play turn based on a grid... but have the option to do Quick Combat.

Both Games have tech trees that are great.

However this game shines with what you can do.  Firstly you start out with a hero.  This hero can choose from one of five tech trees, and each tech tree has around 3 paths, with only 1 you will be able to max out, so lots of deferent playthroughs  in the combat if you change your hero.

In Civ you can get bored when you are building stuff, but in this world it has NPS, monsters that roam, quests, loot to find, epic monsters.  So you take your hero out to level up.

So if I take my hero and 2 mages.  We all get xp if we survive a battle.  The mage can level up and also I can custom creat units which is epic.  With this you can make mages wear plate armour if you fancy it.  It really is epic.

The more you do in the world your fame will increase and you'll get other hereos to help you.

All in all... A BLAST... I played 24 hours straight, playing as the Necomancer Mage in a Large classic map.  Also dipped into the scenerio which is a story line verson of the game, teachign you about the npc and monsters you will find in classic mode.

I'll give this 100% as it is such an iteration of CIV in a fantasy world.  If CIV VI takes this approach it would be great, but otherwise this game has it cooking and it tastes great.  Have FUN!

reviewText:
I haven't played the previous entries in this series so I went in with not many preconceived ideas about what to expect.

I know there were some issues with the earlier games, but Legendary Heroes is a very solid 4x title.

There is a lot of diversity in the game in terms of unit design choices, heroes and city developement.

Each playable faction is unique, and even though the differences seem subtle at first, this uniqueness becomes more apparent as the game progresses. There is a LOT to learn.

Like most 4x games, it is a bit overwhelming at first, but it quickly grows on you and you settle in to get your empire up and running.

There is a lot of challenge to be found in both the early and later game stages. Monsters roam the land and they range very widely in power between pushovers and godlike. Especially so for your weak early armies and champions. Knowing when to leave a challnge or quest for later is critical in keeping your troops and heroes safe.

The AI is also actually decently competent. I lost one of my cities easily early on and got routed in my bid to take over an enemy city a few times.

The strategic battles are one of my favorite parts of the game. You can easily lose a battle even with an overwhelming force if you make bad choices. It is a much better system than the static system of games like Civ 5 and Warlock: Master of the Arcane. You actually fight battles on a tactical map where positioning and ability use are important.

My only real gripe is that diplomacy is a lot less developed than some other 4x games. Hopefully the developers will improve on that in future updates.

A solid and fun game overall if you are a fan of 4x games.

reviewText:
Verdict: This is the 4x game I always wanted. A grand turn-based strategy game, comparable to Civilization IV but in a gorgeous high-fantasy setting with tactical battles and RPG elements. Most significantly for me, it is fully customisable: design your own faction, leader and units to suit your personal playstyle and role-play. Longer games have stability issues, but I fixed mine by turning off anti-aliasing. 8/10

Story: It may be misleading to speak of story in a game like this, and I have not yet played the campaign scenario. The premise of the world, elaborated here from previous Elemental games, is interesting enough. And the customisation allows you to create your own story as you please. 6/10

Gameplay:  Despite some AI and balance issues, the gameplay is solid and very engaging. It’s not long before that classic Civilization “one more turn” syndrome sets in and takes over, and single games can easily steal away 20-30 hours. Though the fashion in 4x strategy is towards hexagons, square-based maps do the job here, and it is fun to explore rich landscapes dense with monsters, treasure and quests to fulfill. City and resource management are interesting, and it’s satisfying to see your metropolises grow and your empire expand. Research is broken into three tech trees (Civic, Warfare, Magic) you advance separately, making it a strategic choice of where your focus will be. Tactical battles are fun, if a bit on the simple side; tactics emerge solely from your unit design and the composition of your armies, without regard for other factors such as terrain. Auto-resolve can be a bit wonky, and can sometimes beat otherwise unwinnable battles, but it is not game-breaking. The UI is a masterpiece and provides all the information you need to manage your empire. Detailed faction and unit customisation are what tie all these factors together and make Fallen Enchantress a superior experience to similar 4x games.  9/10

Graphics: The graphics will appear a bit dated to some, but the art style fits the unique setting nicely resulting in a somewhat cartoony, but still beautiful, dark and broken world. 7/10

Sound/Music: The sound is not exceptional (ambiance is decent), but the music is great with some truly epic themes to conquer to.  7/10

On the whole, a great game that I would recommend to any strategy fans.

reviewText:
After playing this game for a long time, it is clear that it was tested/coded by morons. There are way too many stupid bugs that should never have made it out of QA. I would be ashamed to be listed as a QA tester or QA lead for this game. Bugs such as turning off special video elements causing fire based creatures to disappear is plain stupid.  Having default trained units that have plate or chain armor perks when the FACTION can't use such armor is just plain sloppy. Units stacking on themselves in tactical combat is  lazy. Armies stacking on top of hostile" AI units in strategic view is sloppy.

The AI is horrible. I would be ashamed to be listed as a coder for it.

The graphics artists did a really good job. The music score is well done and appropriate for the game. The low number of maps provided are nicely drawn. The side/story quests are nicely done.  The faction political/trade interface is sound. Unfortunately
date:
these aspects of the game cannot dwarf the incompetence of the "coders" and "testers" above. This game had a very strong and good idea but was ruined by poor execution.

I would rate this game far below Microprose Birth of the Federation and LucasArts Star Wars Rebellion. These two games are over a decade old.

Until they fix these issues with the core game
recommended: I will not bother with any of the expansions. I won't waste my time on any of their newer projects. Thank you for the list of people who worked on this game
hoursPlayed: I will be sure to avoid any future projects listing any of the coders/testers as leads."

reviewText:
Fallen Enchantress is a turn based strategy game with a lot of unique systems that just don't come together to be terribly enjoyable in my opinion.

Knowing nothing about the book series this game is tied to and finding the graphics and art style really boring is a huge killer for me.  The game can take as long as a game of Civilization V (3-5 hours) but it doesnt offer the appeal to me that Civ does, it moves a little slower and doesnt open up quite as much Civ can.  While being able to make your own units and customizing your heroic characters is interesting in concept the game doesnt really give you very much to play with because depending on your race and character class the optimal path of creation is clear and wavering from it is not worth doing.  So while I may be able to make my own character who can blow apart foes with some great magical missles it seems like 9/10 characters are going to do that anyway and I get left witih a rather repetative experience that takes hours.  To go back to the previous comparison, Civ V can recieve similar review but the amount of variation between games and the humor of making a George Washington who rules a Shinto regilious state is much more entertaining to me personally.  I also found the difficulty curve to be confusing beyond all belief.  Some games were so easy I couldnt lose if I wanted and one difficulty level up I couldnt survive more than an hour or so without being completely wiped out.

On a positive note the game does have some pretty decent AI that does seem to know how to handle all the different races equally well, no one race or hero seems to overpowerd when the computer controls them.  The amount of customization the game gives you is nice though the usefullness is questionable and the fact that everytime you create something the game asks if it can post it to facebook kind of kills that as a feature.

Overall I dont think this is worth getting, 4/10 not the worst thing I've ever gotten on steam but one thing I know I would never tell anyone to try.

reviewText:
Verdict: This is the 4x game I always wanted. A grand turn-based strategy game, comparable to Civilization IV but in a gorgeous high-fantasy setting with tactical battles and RPG elements. Most significantly for me, it is fully customisable: design your own faction, leader and units to suit your personal playstyle and role-play. Longer games have stability issues, but I fixed mine by turning off anti-aliasing. 8/10

Story: It may be misleading to speak of story in a game like this, and I have not yet played the campaign scenario. The premise of the world, elaborated here from previous Elemental games, is interesting enough. And the customisation allows you to create your own story as you please. 6/10

Gameplay:  Despite some AI and balance issues, the gameplay is solid and very engaging. It’s not long before that classic Civilization “one more turn” syndrome sets in and takes over, and single games can easily steal away 20-30 hours. Though the fashion in 4x strategy is towards hexagons, square-based maps do the job here, and it is fun to explore rich landscapes dense with monsters, treasure and quests to fulfill. City and resource management are interesting, and it’s satisfying to see your metropolises grow and your empire expand. Research is broken into three tech trees (Civic, Warfare, Magic) you advance separately, making it a strategic choice of where your focus will be. Tactical battles are fun, if a bit on the simple side; tactics emerge solely from your unit design and the composition of your armies, without regard for other factors such as terrain. Auto-resolve can be a bit wonky, and can sometimes beat otherwise unwinnable battles, but it is not game-breaking. The UI is a masterpiece and provides all the information you need to manage your empire. Detailed faction and unit customisation are what tie all these factors together and make Fallen Enchantress a superior experience to similar 4x games.  9/10

Graphics: The graphics will appear a bit dated to some, but the art style fits the unique setting nicely resulting in a somewhat cartoony, but still beautiful, dark and broken world. 7/10

Sound/Music: The sound is not exceptional (ambiance is decent), but the music is great with some truly epic themes to conquer to.  7/10

reviewText:
It's like Heroes of Might and Magic and Sid Meiers Civ series had a baby. I see some criticism in the reviews but frankly I find them unfounded.

Unlike the Civ series, there is always something to do if you feel like it. The game encompasses exploring, RPG, strategy, empire building, tactical combat kin to the Age of Wonders game and much more.

One of my favourite parts of the game is that you can design your own hero and in time design your own troop units. As always, as it is with any game, it takes some time to get a feel for how everything works, and usually when I've learned what I need I don't find the game so intruiging anymore. But this game has me going on and on. Do I recommend it? Oh Yeah!

If you kinda liked Age of Wonders, Heroes of Might and Magic and Sid Meiers Civ, this game is for you.

Have you ever played any CiV game and thought something was missing? reviewText:
Allow me to ask the following questions?

- Do you like turned based gameplay?
- Do you like Roleplaying Games (RPGs)?
- Do you like kingdom/empire building?
- Do you like customization?

If you said 'yes' to all of these questions, then you are going to enjoy this title.

Elemental: Fallen Enchantress was released back in 2012 as a 4x, turn-based tactics game that mixes elements of the 'Civilization' series with kingdom/empire building, development of your research, and defending yourself from both man and horde. While the 'Heroes of Might and Magic' elements are deeply rooted with customization, the ability to custom make your king (or queen) with what skills, specialization, and even their appearance and weapon. The same can be said for your military units. As you can make them either man or woman, what their weapon is and what their armor and skills are. This though, is the stand-alone expansion which is the same game, but with the added content.

Peronsally from my standpoint on this game, I've already spent about ten hours playing it and I love it. The customization is the biggest factor for me and the mods available for this title is amazing. The only negative I see is price on steam, it being $39.99, along with all the DLC being around $30 ($29.94) in price, I'd wait you either have the funds to buy or it to go on sale.

Regardless, I think its an amazing title and it deserves a chance if you are into fantasy, turn-based games or city-builders.

reviewText:
The problem with Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes is *not* simply that it lacks Artificial Intelligence, but that lacks any intelligence at all. The amount of noise simply overwhelms the information and that is a design flaw that permeates the game. The designers simply do not understand that communication is about *meaning*, and you cannot meaningfully communicate if everything that you say is interrupted by something else, which in turn has been interrupted . Or that you drown out what is important by endlessly repeating statements about the irrelevant. Granted that these half-spoken communications eventually unwind off the stack to finally speak the rest of what they were supposed to have said, but the connection between pieces has been lost.

Stacked Modal dialogs that are half-statements of things interrupted is an idiotic paradigm beyond comprehension. Yet this is the paradigm that the designers of Fallen Enchantress have built into the control loop of the game.

But the basic principles of communication are not just abused in this manner.

Some guy will complain that you are intruding on his territory, but not tell you where. So that intrusion could be a transient event created by an automated scout or it could actually be a meaningful complaint about an army. But you don't know which because city boundaries are often not clear. All that you know is that something has happened someplace and maybe you should do something about it if you could.

Some alert will announce that there are enemies in your territory, and it has announced it for dozens of turns. But the alert is not relevant because the beasts are holed-up in their cave and still remain too strong to take on. That information then should be check-boxed and excluded from the alert, but instead it is repeated turn after turn, to the point that it is eventually ignored. Yet *all* intrusions use the same alert and so ignoring that one can leave other, more serious intrusions, ready to pounce from the bushes.

Tactical combat takes place in an arena that reflects the locale, and there are often building and trees in the area. This is a nice aesthetic touch and a sensible paradigm. But unfortunately, in Fallen Enchantress, those buildings and trees are fixed objects and do not become transparent when the space gains focus. That means that these objects can obscure armies and placements behind them, leaving you blind when you try to move into that space or attack enemies on it.

Possible movement squares of armies are highlighted as are those of the opposing armies. Unfortunately, the base color is light blue, and the movement squares of friends is light green. Closely examined, the difference is clear, yet errors in placement are often made because those colors are transparent pastels and not easily differentiated with a quick glance. Again, clear communication was not the objective and so it doesn't take place.

There are various other problems, and others have talked about them and the poor AI in the game, but the problem is deeper than any. The problem is that the developers do not understand what they are doing. They might be competent programmers but they do not understand design and the necessary flow of communication and execution that makes working within the world they've created a pleasure. This game works, but working within it is a pain because you have to fight with it to get what you want done.

Behind the mess is a game worth playing, but you'll need a fair bit of patience to reach it.

reviewText:
This game helped me keep my sanity during my long period free of the internet, escaping to the PC when I could to play this.  It crashes, it has it's oddities, and it knows how to pull you along on a string. It is pure 4x game bliss, and let me explain why.

It'd do this game little respect comparing it to the civilization series, but given that you found cities with buildings you can create, research technology, and amass armies, it's pretty much inevitable, given that, in retrospect, it's everything LIKE civilization. That said, there are a few features that I am absolutely enthralled with, that make this game like no other.

1.) FACTION CREATION
2.) HERO CREATION
3.) UNIT CREATION
right down to the beards on your archers and the capes on your amazon squad of enchantresses on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed wargs.

These three features, combined with the fantasy setting, place this at the top of my reccomendation list. Get this while it's cheap, if you are looking for an awesome single player experience.

reviewText:
By far, the closest I have ever found to a remake of Masters of Magic (MOM).  It is kind of like Civ 3 or 4, but with heros, items, and turn-based tactical combat instead of a automatic random number generator.

The AI is pretty good for the start of middle of a game, but once you cross a certain power threshold (usually 2x to 3x as powerful as them) you can win just by declaring war and then asking for their surrender.  The only down side, is that when they surrender, you get their main guy as a hero, but the rest of the citys and outposts get destroyed.

Overall, great game, but Eador might be a better verson of MOM, but this is the 100% spiritual reincarnation.

reviewText:
This is fun. FE is faster moving than Eador and there are more options for levelling up the Heroes. You alos get more Heroes than in Eador. Eador is slow, and I have only played it on tiny shards, so the Warrior Blitz tactic worked there. I think FE:LH is a good game. Of course, it does not have the monster units found in Eador, but it takes a long time in Eador to get them.

FE has city building as well. The cities can become one of several types: Town for $$, Conclave for research and Fortress for unit production. Oh, and FE has research. I went thru the whole research trees in my first game. In the second I had Slow Research selected, and it was nive and slow.

Your Heroes may select from multiple paths. I created a Leader with Life and Water speels and healed my units to victory many times. I put another Champion in the same army and he was the tank warrior, very cool.

I like playing FE:LH.

reviewText:
This is fun. FE is faster moving than Eador and there are more options for levelling up the Heroes. You alos get more Heroes than in Eador. Eador is slow, and I have only played it on tiny shards, so the Warrior Blitz tactic worked there. I think FE:LH is a good game. Of course, it does not have the monster units found in Eador, but it takes a long time in Eador to get them.

FE has city building as well. The cities can become one of several types: Town for $$, Conclave for research and Fortress for unit production. Oh, and FE has research. I went thru the whole research trees in my first game. In the second I had Slow Research selected, and it was nive and slow.

Your Heroes may select from multiple paths. I created a Leader with Life and Water speels and healed my units to victory many times. I put another Champion in the same army and he was the tank warrior, very cool.

I like playing FE:LH.

reviewText:
Love this game. Build your own Soveriegn, choose a race, choose the  strengths and weaknesses of your Kingdom
/Empire and then take on a world overun by monsters and other factions after a cataclysm. You can use the default unit designs they provide or make your own, name them what you want and rename them on the battlefield. Atlar Heavy Infantry to Jamie's Besiegers" for example. This game can by as immersive as you want.

The aim of this 4x game is to successfully manage your faction towards one of 5 victory conditions whilst fending off the awakened monsters of the world and other soveriegns.

If you have played the civilation series you will feel right at home here. Diplomacy suffers alot compared to Civ but this game makes up for it in other ways. Customisable heroes and turn-based battles are examples.

Would have liked to see more customisation options to really go to town with your factions own unique identity and it would have been nice to see some more 'Master Quests'"

reviewText:
This game is obscure, even for a 4X. We all know our Civilizations or Dominions or Alpha Centauris, but I barely know anyone who's heard of this, let alone played it. That being said, this game could be described a rough diamond. The game has some glaring balance issues, and it's a good bit glitchy at times, but the gameplay is solid and rewarding.

Every game begins like any Civilization game, where you found your capital city and then start to explore the world. However, instead of your standard units like Civilization has, you have customized units that you can design yourself. You also have heroes, which are specialty one-man armies that will join your cause from time to time.

If you've played Age of Wonders III, the combat is remarkably similar. When you enter battle, both factions are placed on the opposite side of the battlefield, and you move them into play until they're in range to strike.

The world itself is incredibly detailed. On almost every playthrough, I'll run into a quest or monster that I've never seen before, and every game spawns one of four special areas of the map where you can fight boss-type monsters and aquire extremely rare treasure. Every game brings something new.

PROS:

- Incredibly varied worlds
- Good combat system
- Lots of fluff"
- Wide variety of artifacts and weapons
- Useful character creator

CONS:

- Some factions just plain suck
- Game can be glitchy
date:
particularly when loading saves
- Soundtrack's rather forgettable

FINAL VERDICT

First off
recommended: buying this game with all the DLC will leave you homeless. When our Lord and Savior Gaben blesses this software with the glorious green of a sale
hoursPlayed: snatch it up as soon as you can. You won't be disappointed."

reviewText:
The game degrades memorywise the longer you play. So first it gets slower, then the waterlevel disappears, then wrong colors and missing parts happen all over the game. If this isn´t already annoying, the most encountered bug in the game (trying to go to the main menue and reloading a gamesave makes the game crash entirely) completes it. The game is like a kid, that tries to ram too much sweets(data) down his throat and almost suffocates trying it. If they would fix this single problem and you ignore the other bugs, the game could go as a computergame. But for now it is what it is...unstable.

Now just my taste:
Comparing Fallen Enchantres with Master of Magic is a little bit bold. MoM had better suited spells in the line from weak to powerful, even many of them not the usual fireball stuff we have in this game. And I used most of them in the game, not like here, where I only use few and the rest never or rare. Plus the computer ai loves to use inferior spells more in combat like useful spells: for example giant grow instead of healing an almost dead unit (seen often enough). MoM had buildings, that brought new features, not new (and always same) boni. MoM had units and creatures, that aren´t effect catchers with the appearance of Sauron and oversized, absolutly stupid designed weapons. And erm....MoM had alot less platitudes in it´s game texts. I always roll my eyes, when I have to read the subtexts of most characters.... :) It is like a 6 year old trying to produce somekind of epic zitate.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game. It's similar to games like Civilization or Warlocks: Master of the Arcane but the details are all heavily changed to create a very unique entry into the genre. Given how much there are to games like this, I'll just highlight things that stood out to me that I liked and didn't like.

What I liked:
+Each leader/faction felt significantly different from the other factions -- There's a lot of different units, spells and bonuses that each faction gets to make you get a different experience playing with each one.

+The game's combat is really fun -- You can play in a top down view isometric grid type combat or auto-calc. The auto-calc is weird, so sometimes you suffer some bad losses and sometimes you win a battle you could have never won, however I found this feature to be more in my favor than ever against me and I normally only did it in situations where I would obviously win to save time. Additionally you can create very large armies with very powerful units so that a combat victory is much more feasible than in a game like Civilization.

+The random stuff on the map is quite fun -- The game has a quest system which, while basic, is actually pretty fun in short bursts. Additionally there is the option to have a ton of monsters and animals to keep yourself busy with them. On top of all that there is a dedicated area on each map where a ludicrously over-powered monster reigns who you can fight for some sweet items.

+The hero system is pretty fun -- At first heros seem awesome. Heroes can use spells, equip gear, have special properties that buff your army or a city they occupy. In combat they aren't useful later in game because their stats just don't scale well, but their spells/city/group buffs can be worth it. Each hero is very different so it's something to explore.

+The city system is really good and has great progression -- Each city levels up and as they level you can choose a specialization for them, offering bonuses to that particular city. This is really cool and offers you a new level of customization. I found myself regularly creating 1 resource heavy city and then making several combat cities to amass a horde of overpowered soldiers.

What I didn't like:
-The game isn't technically perfect -- Sometimes you try to click something on the map and the game has it's own mind. Sometimes walking to a particular place is a real pain. These were fairly minimal interruptions, but over the course of 50 hours it was enough to make me complain about it. Also as mentioned earlier the auto-calcuation battles can be wonky. Sometimes I would start a fight manually, then once I realized I couldn't win, I'd auto-calc to end my suffering. However, I'd end up winning a fair amount of those battles somehow. It didn't bother me because it was a nice surprise, but it may be a break in realism for others.

-There is a steep learning curve -- The game has a lot of stuff to it, much like civ. The difference is that in this game the combat is more present, so you do need to be more up to snuff. I found myself being demolished in about 3 (...practice) games before I could finally conquer others, even on easier settings. The monsters can be a real threat, which is nice later on, but at the start it can be overwhelming.

If you like any sort of strategy, please try this game. I was sad I was so hesistant in buying it (I didn't buy it until it hit $10, easily worth $40). Please note this review is based on the game without any of the DLC.

reviewText:
This game is a chore. The tutorial literally has you doing taxes, and it doesn't get any better in the game proper. Also, just to start the game, you need to create and validate a Stardock account.

A separate account and presumably always-online DRM. For a singleplayer-only game. What!?

The graphics are unappealing, DeviantArt amateur quality. Even the art style choice can't justify how unfinished and poorly polished everything looks, especially the characters. Aside from lacking graphical definition, the characters are also rather bland and unremarkable - this does not even feel like playing a Pretty Good hero.

The sounds are okay, but the soundscape feels really rushed. The ambiance is composed of short, irritating loops and the music starts to jar very quickly. I preferred to mute the game and just listen to my own music or podcasts while trying to slog my way through.

I think that's enough bashing, the game really isn't worth your money. I only mention these things to give you some idea what I base my negative outlook on. Buyer Beware.

PS. If you're looking for Fantasy 4X, you're better off replaying Heroes of Might and Magic IV (€9 on GOG.com, DRM-free). The HoMM series had lemons in the later editions, too, but luckily there are modern alternatives like Age of Wonders and Warlock, each with their foibles and DLCs, but higher quality, more entertaining, and more satisfying than this drek.

reviewText:
Lots of cool options and custimization for both hero units and regular units. Factions have slightly different play styles, though it's nothing drastic. You can even create your own factions along with a main character for it.

It has a bit of a learning curve, but not too steep. The action tends to slow down after you defeat all the lower level creatures in the area, and have to start venturing towards other players. Diplomacy was simple for me: I liked having clear answers and numerical values during trades instead of having to guess whether your diplomat is skilled enough to overcome the hatred between your nations, as seen in other 4X titles.

If you like 4X games as well as RPGs, I strongly recommend this game. Doesn't seem to have a strong story line, but if you can invest in giving your own characters a voice, there's plenty to commit to.

reviewText:
So I actually killed a day playing this game. Needless to say, I wont be buying it. While im using a pentium i3 with 8gb of memory, the game ran OK, but ending a turn generally took about 10-20 seconds to process everything. You will be ending turns ALOT in this game  because everything takes forever to make.

I decided to forgo the tutorial and quickly realized this was a civ style game. Unlike civ, you can only build cities on green tiles that have resources. Due to a mistake I made with my settlers by clicking the outpost button, and the inability to undo a turn I was left at a disadvantage while it took another 6 turns to produce another settler. During this time, the AI hemmed me in and I was stuck to two cities the whole game. I kept playing thinking I could research and negotiate my way out of it. Impossible.

After researching everything I needed to earn capital quickly, I paid the most powerful player to declare war on my neighbor. This had virtually no effect as they both continued to grow more powerful. I should have known because when my neighbor declared war on me, his army consisted of two scouts and three archers and that was it. All of the AI's soldiers were garrisoned in the cities with 400+ attack power. With a limitation of 6-7 slots in an army and NO system for reinforcing one army with another it becomes impossible to dislodge them.

After figuring out how rigid the game is, I just stopped playing. A day wasted, but money saved.

reviewText:
I've never heard of this game before but I saw it at a 'free weekend' and, remembering my fond feelings for turn-based strategies, decided to give it a try. Well, after playing through the night and finishing one random game, one thing is for sure: I'm not going to buy it after the time runs out.

This game is tedious. I started with the tutorial and, boy, were the introductory videos long and unnecessary! I got to the end of only one of them, skipping all the others, and didn't feel like I was missing something. Then there was the main game. For me it went like this: settle down, start expanding - ooh, it's getting interesting - die trying to explore, meet neighboors, avoid their units and wandering monsters while trying to explore and expand, upgrade your cities and lose your units on the way to join main guy's army - repeat for many turns until you know the map - start negotiating, get into a war, sign a peace treaty - rinse and repeat, that's where I lost the last of my interest for this game, during those many turns where nothing happened - finally be strong enough to follow the main storyline and immediately after wait again for who knows how long for new units to be trained in place of the fallen ones. Yeah, boring.

I got three endings: the ultimate spell (which I did only out of curiosity, not knowing that it will end the game), by losing to the final dragon behind the gates and by killing it (last two with the use of cheats because of the difficulty jump - I could easily kill any monster or AI unit on the map but this thing obliterates me in, like, three turns? Yeah, no, I'm not grinding for that - and by the way: those cheats? Did not help much). I didn't try to conquer all the other nations just because I couldn't be bothered anymore and wanted to be done with it. And my rating was always 4/10 (I think) despite having, like, twenty fully upgraded cities and finishing all reasearch and quests.

Also, this game doesn't have window mode which incredibly bothered me and the loading process took way longer than it should. Maybe my machine isn't powerful enough, although I thought it didn't have to be to play a top-down strategy game! On the technical side of the things, thank god there is an auto-battle option, cause I don't think I would have gotten this far without it! Never played a battle on my own (except the final dragon one but that one doesn't count) and immensely grateful for that.

TL;DR

Actually, this game is not so bad - for the first few hours. After that, if you're not a fan of the wainting game, it becomes too much. Maybe it's supposed to be played in short sessions, who knows, but for me one run was more than enough.

Never would've thought of buying this game before; certain that I'd not now.

reviewText:
Honestly, I don't know how to rate this game. So in this review I'm going to talk myself through formulating a rating, and maybe you'll see why I am so confused by how to rate this game.

- To start lets point this out. This game is HORRIBLY optimized. I averaged 40 FPS as low as 20 and I have a beast rig. But I averaged these fps on EVERY graphical setting. Max, medium, and low. Did the devs even aim for 60fps? I guess not.
+ These graphics are good enough for me, I enjoy them. But a lot of persons today may want something better. The game was released in 2012 though. We didn't have any Witcher 3 graphics back then, remember?
+/- The sounds were decent, but nothing to write home about.

reviewText:
When I first purchased Elemental way back years ago, I had every hope it would make for a great table top RPG platform as well as the regular strategy game it was designed to be. When I got my copy I was able to see what could be, but it was still an “alpha” game… So I let it go,  kept checking the progress and changes overtime, but nothing got my attention. Then along came 1.7 update and much of what I read I liked so I purchase Legendary Heroes.

A BIG WOW!

I am so happy the developers never gave up. This is very much what they had promised back when they were making the first Elemental. There is still room for improvement (lots of potential for growth and expansion), but the main concept is all there!

So, soon as  they let us make scenarios using the “workshop”,  a custom monster toolset (like the spell toolset) and add a hot seat feature to the game it will appeal to many D&D table top players like myself.

I love the way the mechanics and AI  have developed and evolved/improved, I love the customization aspect so, so, so, very much. Changing gear is actually visible in game play, love the way cities can level as well as almost everything else, we just need equipment to level as well (hopes).

The artwork is splendid. I have loved the art from day one! So perfect for this kind of game, the way the story is presented through text and that unique artwork makes me feel like I am actually reading a D&D campaign and I can get my fiends involved (rolling dice to make decisions, character customization, etc.) we played all night as if we were playing table top, and we never once looked at the time, it was great fun, different, but not so different that it did not work. It is thanks to the freedom to customize just about everything that makes this game so rewarding and usable as a tool for a good old fashion table top game. If you have an imagination and fun friends to play with give this a try. ( mind you we are doing this without hot seat or multiplayer, image if we had that!)

In short I am very happy that my bias for DLC’s went away almost instantly, “sell me as many DLC's for this game as you want! if they are useful and enhances the game like the current DLC’s.  If you love fantasy strategy games give this version of the game a try
date: you will love it more and more every turn you take
recommended: there is something different and new for your imagination to create in good fun! Recommend!"

reviewText:
I haven't reviewed many games, but I've logged more hours into this game than any other in my library so far, including Skyrim. It's a very detailed strategy game that includes Civilization style kingdom/empire building from a starting date (after a world-shattering cataclysm) until you achieve one of multiple possible victories over the competition. Similarities to Civilization include focusing research to unlock new city improvements, resources, units, and abilities; expanding your country through exploration or conquest; making trade agreements, treaties, and war with other factions; and turn-based actions for all levels of the game.

However, this game also includes a lot of plot. There are some default scenarios you can play to see what the underlying relationship is between each of the sovereigns. Even if you choose to just do a custom map or pre-set map without a scenario, you are able to control a soverign character and heroes s/he recruits to complete quests, explore the map, and level up customized ability trees. This comes into play into the larger faction planning because leveling these characters unlocks abilities and bonuses that can boost any other aspect of the game and can lead to extremely powerful units that can trounce through ordinary enemies. There's not as many factions as similar games, but the bonuses are fairly unique to each sovereign and allow for enough variation that trying different game types is a good way to learn new strategies.

The fantasy theme is also very fun. There was a lot of effort and creative writing with the incredible number of quests and lore that is inlcuded in each game. The DLC adds even more.

Overall, I just haven't gotten bored with this game. It's a lot of fun and worth the full price, though I did find it on sale when I purchased it. That said, if I had played a demo beforehand, I would have gladly paid the full price if no sale was offered. I had no qualms about paying for DLC, each of the ones I have so far were worth it.

reviewText:
first impression, based on free trial.

++ this game is very curstmizable.
+ you have multiple factions and multiple magic schools
+ you can select traits for both your faction and your leader.
+ you can reqruit heroes and level them as you wish.
+ you can equip your leader your heroes and your basic units as you wish.
+ you can paint anything as you wish.

this is all great! and i would love this in almost any other game! however the game is just no fun...
combat is weird... with unit turns based on their initiative... which sound logical, and some board games have similar mechanics... but it doesnt feel right...

while you can customize all of your units, and the individual assets are pretty decent... the game somehow still looks very dated and ugly... which is weird...

the map is square grid based, and does not look fun... the quests structures and everything else are just randomly splattered around... and it just doesnt look/feel good....  civ V random maps are beautiful and feel natural... these don't...

this game has so many cool mechanics... and most of them are implemented pretty well... yet somehow it just doesnt work :(

reviewText:
Well, this is no Master of Magic. I picked it up on steam sale, and I have to say I am surprised to see how little was done to improve it. Fundamentally, this is balanced and slightly polished Elemental War of Magic.

Positives:
*This is a strategy/builder game with magic
*Tactical combat
*Unit customization

Negatives:
*AI is weak
*Graphics are dated
*GUI is poorly designed

reviewText:
Are you ready for a strategic RPG with tactical combat and a vast world to explore?

Well too bad! First you need to build your first city, then set research, then maybe you can wait a few turns to build a scout, then maybe find something interesting outside of a two tile radius of where you started the game, and a few turns later, maybe finish researching sticks with pointy ends so you can make spearmen.

Or in other words, in spite of how this game tries to sell itself, this game is basically just Civilization with a new coat of paint and a spellbook mechanic.  (Notably, spellbooks are also tied to tech trees, so you get even more sit and watch a progress bar fill up" fun.)

One would think that after over two decades
date: the formula for these games would be getting refined - even Civilization itself has
hoursPlayed: done much to try to lessen the micromanagement - but this game and the other low-budget Civ clones prove that some people are just averse to new ideas.\n\nIn essence
voteText: the point of this game is to build cities
helpfulPercent: expand cities
votesHelpful: kill barbarians - I mean monsters - and finally get a conquest/diplomacy/research/whatever ending.\n\nThere's also a unit customization screen

commentsCount: you can make one class of soldier have a red hat instead of a green one to tell them apart more easily.\n\nI can't recommend this game

reviewText:
Someone tried to mix Civilization with HoM&M, not successfully. I'd rather play Warlock Master of Arcane serie.

- obscure interface,
- maps feel very small and not interesting, there was not enough space for another city on medium map, wtf? I could build outposts for resources at the least.
- shallow combat, imho failed unit initiative system,
- no hexes, neither on main map nor battle map - Civ manages well without them I admit, but not the case here,
- no separate city view and not clikable buildings, not even a tooltip what it is and what it does.
- obscure interface (doubly so), especially city management (wait, there is city management at all?)

Disclaimer: I played during free weekend and I cannot recommend what I tried to like. Maybe on sale? And I hate wasted potential in games, so common these days.

reviewText:
It is some Civ+HoMM+Master of Magic+whoknowswhat. There is a lot to like in the game, if you like the above mentioned ones. However, it is more simplified than civ. I liked playing it during the free weekend, but somehow this game feels unfinished... or well, not enough tested. Annoyingly small icons. Unable to handle changes in long production lists. etc

Character, unit development is great. City development is less, but for me it was still ok.
I miss battle set-up, this random drop of units has no tactical consideration, or at least very little. I don't expect a Total War setup, but something.

Altogether it WILL BE a good game, there are only little things to fix. €10 (€9.24) on 75%?...I'll wait a little more. One could say €10 is not much, well in some countries this amount of money is more worth than this game is right now (eg. the price of 8 beer in a pub).

reviewText: My initial impression is: How have I not heard about this before? It feels like this game was tailor made for me. It's a mix of Civ and Heroes of Might and Magic without stripping down the hefty ideas from those two games. This is a very deep strategy game that allows for a lot of customisation - a sentence that always wins me over. So far I have been able to create an evil mage warlord from a fantasy story I wrote a long time ago and live out his career. The game is moulding itself around my play style rather than the other way around which is an absolute win. I forsee many late nights with this one. It's like discovering HoMM3 all over again...

reviewText:
Hi, I've just played this game during the trial weekend. As other people have said, this is Civilization meets HoMM, both of which are series that I have enjoyed very much. There is also a resemblance to Age of Wonders. Many of the elements of this game are very well done.
Pros:
+Turn Based Combat System is well executed in general
+Graphics are decent for Turn-Based 4x games
+Customisable Characters
+Interesting weapon array
+Interesting skills available
+Quest system is really cool

Cons:
-Game is a bit too complex (for me), as an RPG is good, as a 4x is good, but both is a bit confusing and hard to manage
-Hard to understand city system and resources (not clear enough what buildings actually do and how the city evolves)
-Too easy to build pioneers, cities should be hard to build!!

In conclusion, I feel this game would appeal to fans of civilization who like to play the game on normal or slow settings and fans of total war. This game requires a lot of effort to understand the mechanics but it *might be* worth it. For me though, I didn't feel it was replayable enough as every game seemed to feel the same (I just wanted things to hurry up!), and perhaps I missed out on important aspects of the game. I'm giving it a 'Yes' recommendation as there is no 'Maybe' button and it was nice to give a trial weekend.

Recommend? Maybe.

reviewText: So I picked up this game for the free weekend, having never actually played a build civilization stratagy game before. A stand-a-lone game by Stardock, upon the opening intro I see interesting artwork and fantasy. The story line or plot is pretty basic. You choose between 10 soverign or heros, who aim to rule/conquer the world of Elemental. Witch has been torn asunder and is in ruins ripe to be brought together again by cataclysm. The soverigns themselves and their civilizations are very themed and have a style of their own. A unique gameplay for whoever you choose. I selected Magnar. I was drawn to (naturally) by his warlock abilities and the story line of ( I'm a dragon/human thing called a Quendar, Were old and ancient and you're not. So I shall make slaves and use fire and death magic to rule the weak. ) Cool huh? A short tuturial and you can jump into the game.  Using you'r soverign you build and take over the world of Elemental. Build settlements and watchposts to increase your economy and research warfare/civilization/magic. It took a while to get the hang of all the micro-managing but after a while I think I got the hang of it. More heros DO join your civilization, while it grows in fame and fortune. Witch they want a part of , butt chose wisely your heros to your strengths and game play. Also you have to build an army or two to kill wild animals, bandits, undead, demons, trolls, ogres and everything else you can think of in the fantasy world. I was rather impressed by the monster library in the game. During all this you can also pick up quests to complete mainly by killing or collecting things while your doing your build civilization thang. And then you have the other soverigns to deal with ! Oh yeah and there is these huge epic elemental boss guys that'll pop up that'll try to destroy you....This game was interestingly addicting by the fact of I MUST BUILD MY EMPIRE BIGGER.  and level up my soverin and heros to rule the weak. An almost primal urge of destroy and conquer kinda takes over. A lot of content to get lost in while you play It's defineitly a game to pick up if you have a chance.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes is an extremely fun and addictive 4X game in a beautiful setting. Customization is amazing, I always play my own faction and own hero. Tactical combat is really fun and you can play in many different ways. Personally I play it almost like an RPG running around with my hero group and some troups, doing quests, gathering items, slaying monsters and building heroes so strong they can squash enemy empires. The choice is yours.



Highly recommended game, for people who like 4X, RPG and a fantasy setting. 9/10.

Perfect mix of civilization with tactical turn based fantasy combat that keeps me saying just a few more turns, then I'll go to bed. So if you like civilization games, turn based games, empire building games and/or strategy games you can't go wrong with this title.

reviewText: Fallen Enchantress is an awesome mix of Civilization, Spellforce, and King's Bounty. All of these are games I love to pieces. Fallen Enchantress uses the hero and quest system from Spellforce, the Hero leveling and battle system from King's Bounty (with squares instead of hex spaces) and the format of Civilization, with a fantasy twist. Get ready to lose hours of your life playing it!

reviewText: Just not a very good game all around.  First, the graphics are just awful, it feels like the game was developed 10 years ago.\n\nIif you're going to choose to make a fantasy game, you'd better make sure the graphics are up to par.  You can get away with vector-like graphics and single-digit landscape palettes in a Sci-Fi game like GalCiv, but Stardock shows that when it's applied to fantasy, it just doesn't work.  The story and what little art style there is lacks creativity and is pretty uninteresting.

reviewText:
Well, I played this for a grand total of 43 minutes, since it's on free demo on Steam at time of writing. I realise this isn't a full review, 43 minutes isn't very long, but the point of a demo is to entice you to want to play the game further, so I can say the demo failed for me.

Having never played a Fallen Enchantress game before, I found the controls not very intuitive, and felt frustrated a lot of the time. I don't know if there are ways to choose which things you research in what order, clicking on them didn't do squat, so my research carried on automatically. I couldn't easily see when things I was building would finish, or view or edit my building queue. It took quite a while to work out how to combine units into an army, and the relative limitations of army sizes.

Combat is a huge mess. I'm used to being able to wait and move my unit turn further down in the queue, like Heroes of Might & Magic, but instead in this I guess if my unit can't reach the enemy and isn't a long range unit he just has to pass a turn he could still have done *something* in, just not move. Most of my combat turns involved me passing turns, everyone was out of mana pretty much immediately and I wasn't presented with any information on how or when they regained it.
I then ran into a battle in which I had to fight a ghost. The ghost is immune to all physical damage. No one has any mana.
That was when the 43 minutes elapsed and I decided I'd had enough.

reviewText:
As i was running an army pathing, it decides to NOT let me move threw enemy territory as long as do not end the turn in there borders, forcing me to walk around, inwhich incountered a wandering army that oddly enough was in said enemy territories... which as understand roaming monsters will only be agroed to attacking u unless there lair is in your territory...Which for some odd reason AI does not have this limitation.

I lost an unguarded outpost to a weak 3 unit wolf pack that was wandering nowhere near to there lair... WHY do outposts not have atleast have a small garrison of militia like settlements?

Suppose its not much to ask yet really needs to be over-hauled as the amount of unforseen dangers are outragious, so far had terrible quests with sub-par rewards, Really enter a sand golem lair and only recieve a mediocre snake beast? OR enter a lair for a alchemy spell only to realize it costs 100 mana for 100 gildar... wtf is there such terrible rewards??? its almost like only thing quests give you is heroes and that is with aquiring fame, while no same inn will give the same option to recieve quests anymore. Also had a random event of plague... really? Like i have enough to worry about with roaming monsters/beasts now my food reserves are cut in half or lose 20 population OR i suffice for the cure plague spell and that is a wopping 500 mana!!!

SO maybe this is my review yet not really worth the hassle of unbalanced, unreal control of armies... NO formation perks for heroes just a random placement in tactical map. INCLUDING prior rant 5/10
