reviewText:
Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes aspires to be a great game, and all the elements of a good turn based fantasy strategy game are there, unfortunetly, after 40+ hours of playing it, i have to say, while it is addicting, it is not very fun to play it.

I am sure there are people who have lots of fun playing at the start like an ant wich has to be careful where to build it howel least the many wandering beings of power trample it. Scurry around with you units like rats in a field full of cats and larger predators, and pray that none of the monsters, who are at this point unbeatable, notice you.

I know what others playing the game will say, that nothing is unbeatable given time. Well sure, but time is not something you have for it when there are AI rivals on the world, who are absolutly unnaffected by the same creatures building their empires, (And don't you dare claim othervise, i have seen unescorted pioneers of the AI walk around dragons and wandering ogre armies unmolested. And no, they did not have the stealthy trait.) this is frustrating at the least.

That is not to say it cannot be an enjoyable game, and that you could not beat it. (Sometimes easily, even on harder difficulties.) But luck is too much of a factor, and it is infuriating to realise that you are screwed after an hour of playing, because a creature with physical immunity wandered into your territory (And you have no magic yet), or a random event spawned a swarm of giant spiders on top of your capital that is stronger as your entire armed forces.


In a faster game these issues could be looked over, but Fallen Enchantress is Slooowww. I love empire building, i have no problems with a game being slow, but when it is slow, and a bit of bad luck can be game ending, and you have to restart over and over again to get a starting position that is not full of nasties you cannot beat until after midgame tech, that is simply bad design.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I downloaded and played this game during the time period where they allowed it to be played for Free".

Would I pay 40$ for this game? Absolutely not.
Would I pay 30$ for this game? Absolutely not.
Would I pay 20$ for this game? Yes.

This is based off of roughly 10 hours of play time.

FIRST HOUR.
The game has a somewhat clunky UI. It doesn't fully teach the player what to do when it comes to building a city or
recommended: maintaining a city properly once you level up a city and begin to expand. I don't care for a game holding my hand throughout but I feel with a game like this
hoursPlayed: you need to actually teach a player how to get their feet on the ground before thrusting them in the middle of a "Civilization-esque" RTS. I had no idea what to do for the first 45 minutes or so and even afterwards still had to sit and think how to do certain actions. Yes
voteText:
I played through the tutorial. It did not help. Its very basic.

CHARACTER/FACTIONS.
I played with 3 different characters (roughly 3 hours apiece)
helpfulPercent:
2 premade characters and one custom made "Aragorn-like" character that focused on using a bow and buffing his allies. This is where the game shines. Each character and faction is unique and interesting as well as potent if you expand and progress correctly. Creating a character took roughly 10 minutes and was enjoyable through the entire process. One of the things that is very different and seperates this game from others is that your hero levels up and becomes stronger. Skill trees are always a plus.

QUESTING.
One of the activities you can do in the game is do "Quest". Basically your hero walks into an Inn and someone says "Hey
votesHelpful: go across the map and do this. If you succeed
votesTotal:
I'll give you something." Then you do it. It's pretty basic but its something to do and it rewards your hero with neat little items and gear.

WOULD I RETURN.
I would buy the game (I've already deleted it once it regained the 40$ pricetag)
votesFunny: if it dropped in price. I enjoyed the majority of my time and I'd love to go back and see how my character (which was directly based off my Dungeons and Dragons character) dealt with this ominous Black Gate area that was locked off from the rest of the map.\n\nThis game is a STRONG 7/10. Its fun but it definitely has its problems that taint the total product. At the current price I can't recommend it. Wait for the price to drop or a sale THEN buy it."

reviewText:
I immediately bought this when I found out about it because I adore the old Heroes of Might and Magic games and the Age of Wonders franchise, and I really wanted something newer and better to play with my friends.

Those of you who know this game already know what my first problem is... No multiplayer?! I assumed it had multiplayer since every similar game that went before it has multiplayer, but boy was I stupid not to have checked that little detail beforehand. And there won't be any multiplayer in the future either.

Oh well, I like to play those games in single player mode too, so all's not lost... And the gameplay is great. It's better than HoMM and AoW. It really is a step forward, and not only graphically.

But that positive note was dashed almost immediately. This game is buggier than an ant-farm (on windows XP certainly, on windows 7 less so). It used to crash right before it saved (only a game that corrupts its own savegames is more annoying), but still I had to save often because a slew of other things could go wrong, so many actions could lead to crippling or annoying bugs that it isn't possible to sum them up here. After a few updates the saving issue was gone but other bugs popped up. To this day the bugs make this game practically unplayable, and that is a crying shame, because it really is a good game at heart.

7/10 if they get the bugs out. 3/10 as it is right now.

reviewText: My initial impression is: How have I not heard about this before? It feels like this game was tailor made for me. It's a mix of Civ and Heroes of Might and Magic without stripping down the hefty ideas from those two games. This is a very deep strategy game that allows for a lot of customisation - a sentence that always wins me over. So far I have been able to create an evil mage warlord from a fantasy story I wrote a long time ago and live out his career. The game is moulding itself around my play style rather than the other way around which is an absolute win. I forsee many late nights with this one. It's like discovering HoMM3 all over again...

reviewText:
Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes is an odd game to me. Personally, I don't like turn-based games because I don't have the patience to wait for my next turn. But, somehow, I still bought this game because I like the RPG-element in it. Against my expectations I really liked the game because the world looks pretty awesome with the magic and monsters (especially the dragons.. I love dragons). I have spent a lot of time creating new factions and sovereigns because you want to try everything out when you see something new.
NOTE: Sovereigns and heroes are not the same thing in this game.

The point of the game is to build a kingdom/empire, research and defeat or work together with the enemy AI's, kill monsters (there are dragons, giant spiders and some really epic monsters I  haven't encountered yet) and there can be an event going on like the plague, the shroud (can't remember what it was). All in all, you must make a lot of choices; Shall I attack these monsters and leave my base undefended or shall I make a new squad to defend my base while I'm attacking the enemy? Shall I research better armor or do I need to research better economics?

Doing quests around the map gives you items (sometimes unique ones) which your sovereign or hero can equip. Doing quests also increases your fame, fame will get you heroes, heroes will make your army stronger.

I had a bit of problem getting the hang of this game. The tutorial wasn't really helpful which is a shame. By restarting the game a few times you will learn the game step by step. So don't expect to get the hang of it right away.

Pros:
+ Lots of choices between factions and heroes.
+ Nice graphics (world, kingdoms/empires) when zoomed out.
+ Lots of enemies.
+ Challenging.
+ Customizing your own faction and Sovereign.

Cons:
- Most of the battles you will be selecting auto-result (skip the fighting stuff and know the result right away)
- Bad graphics (npc's and some monsters) when zoomed in.
- Hard to get the hang of this game (I suggest watching some youtube video's first).
- When heroes fall they will have permanently decreased stats.
- Unpredictable AI. Sometimes out of nowhere they start a war or are angry.

If I had to give this game a score I would give it a 7.5.

reviewText:
There is eseentially no AI at all. There might as well not even be other factions in the game. They do nothing. You can literally stand next to one of thier cities filled with units,  with one unit of ours, and they won't even come out to kill you.
They might send a pioneer (non combat unit) to take over your undefended outposts, but that's it. This has got to be the weakest AI I've ever seen in any strategy game to date.

It's too bad. The game feels like a pretty good framework for a 4x stratgy game. Really all it is, is you progressing through the tech tree and fighting the romaing monsters for kicks.

The combat would be better if it was more tactical. It's grid based, Most units only move 2 squares in tactical combat which annoys you when you are fighting an enemy with archers who will all concentrate fire on your chanpion. You have to load him up with dodge equipment to kill the dumb AI that just sits there shooting you with arrows. They have mounted units that move more squares, but each faction only gets one flavor. You are _forced_ to use those against archers. Makes eveyr fight the same. Send mounted units to archers, and mop up with everything else. The AI always coincentrates fire on your champion, even if a unit on the board is a bigger threat.

The unit progression makes one unit completely worthless against another. You pretty much find out what the most OP unit for a given faction is and just crank those out. Not much variety in combat that way. As you tech up, there really is no point in using anything but the best unit available.

Some of the roaming monsters are rediculous. They move 5-6x before you even get an action, castin spells that instantly kill everyone. It makes it more of a puzzles to figure out where and how to get units resistant to whatever they cast, rather than a combt.

Everything moves 2 squares at a time on the campaign map, making it a real pain the ♥♥♥♥ to hunt down all the worthless AI's pioneer spam. You can cast a force march to move 3 squares, but it can only be active on one unit at a time.

In summary:
The AI sucks hard and there were a few questionable desing decisions. It can be entertaining for a day or two, but it is no masterpiece.

reviewText: This is an excellent game for anyone with a passing interest in turn based strategy games. I honestly do believe this is the spiritual successor to Age of Wonders or the closest we shall get to it, which is something I've always dreamed would happen.At first I pirated the game and on the second day after I went and purchased it off Steam to support the developers in what way I can, I was that impressed. It has so many layers from the research, the rpg-style exploration and questing to the empire building and warfare. Stardock has really impressed me with how much support they have gone and given this game, it is a light and day difference in terms of quality from the original Elemental to Legendary Heroes and this tells me they really do care about their product and their support for such a great game will not be ending anytime soon. I'll end by saying that the one more turn" feeling we all love and crave has been captured very well so far for me with Legendary Heroes and what more can you ask for with a game like this? Turn based strategy fans shouldn't even hesitate on giving this game a try and spreading the word. I've been greatly impressed with the amount of work and detail put into this game. Cheers!"

I wrote a review for this , that I then deleted because I thought perhaps I was being too harsh.

Nope I was right the first time.

True, this game does have some highlights, and it has some endearing qualities, no doubt about it, so it's not all bad.

I think the problem is that Stardock simply do not know how to program proper AI into their games. The ai is simply given stacked number bonuses of varying sorts, so that it becomes about beating numbers, rather than any kind of creative/clever/mindful strategy.

As such I cannot recommend this game.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying I am NOT a 4x player (infact I didn't even know what that was when I got this game), so this is coming from some one relatively new to the genre.

FE:LH is the perfect example of an intimidating game.  There's just so much going on, so much custimization, so many options, and so much thought process that seems to need to go into every single turn to be successful, to a new player the whole experience can be more then a little overwhelming.

Now that's not inherently a bad thing, obviously its not the game for you if your looking mindless fun, but if you enjoy a good strategic experience, a game having this much meat to it can be a really good thing, and can allow for a tremendous amount of depth and replay value.

What it DOES mean, however, is that its absolutely crucial that the game has a top notch tutorial to ease a new player into the complexities the game has to offer.  There are various ways this can be accomplished, though my favorites have always been games which provide multiple missions/quests which start with only a small portion of the game available, and incremently add on more and more until by the end the player has had time to at least begin to understand each aspect of the game and is not putting it all together.

Unfortunately, that is not the case with FE:LH.  The single player campaigns, while enjoyable, are not very informative or what I'd consider good learning tools.  Although there is a dedicated tutorial, its not very long, it mainly just shows you how" to do a handful of things
recommended: providing very little information as to the why
hoursPlayed: and generaly leaving the players head spinning from the massive information dump.  It's reminsicent of some fighting games whose tutorials invovle asking you to do a bunch of a characters special moves
voteText: you do them
helpfulPercent: and then the tutorial is over.  You come away knowing these are things you can do
votesHelpful: but not really knowing when or why you should do them
votesTotal: and it was all over so fast you probably won't even remember half of the moves once your in a match.\n\nDespite the lack of new player friendliness
votesFunny: I'm still giving this game a recommend.  Why?  Because I'm finding that if you're willing to endure a pretty terrible introductory experience and learn the concepts of the game the hard way
commentsCount: the actual game itself is quite well made and actually pretty darn fun.  I honestly feel that if this game had a quality tutorial this would be one of the better PC games out there
column16: maybe even a must own.  As it is though
column17: it takes a very special kind of dedicated player (or some one already familar with the 4x genre) to spend the hours learning things the hard way it takes to actually get to the fun part where you know what your doing and your making meaningful choices instead of random ones
column18: so keep this in mind before purchasing."

reviewText:
Got it from a giveaway, thank you kind stranger! :)

On to the review:
-Game itself is very interesting. For starters, you can customize your character so that you can choose what type you want it to be or you can just play with the pre-selected ones. As for the mechanics, its quite hectic. You face other sovereigns in the map and its practically 'the faster, the better'. You need to outpace your enemies in building your city, training your units, and collecting resources for enchantments. This game requires a lot of time, and if you are quite busy, then this could mean that you cannot play it to your heart's content. However, if you love strategy games , then this could fit your bill. Personally, i like the game. As a battle realms lover, i have always loved outpacing my enemies in building our bases and farming resources, and these elements are all present in this game but with much, much more content.
-On the flipside, game is buggy. It frequently crashes and sometimes requires me to restart my pc/laptop. I also found it a bit annoying that they require you to sign-up in their site, i mean for what purpose really? I sure do hope that the bugs will eventually be fixed.

reviewText: This game has one of the most boring and unhelpful tutorials that I have ever seen. Considering that a good amount of work seems to have gone into constructing it, this is actually kind of astounding. One of the most obvious problems is the very bland narration of the instructional videos that play before each section of the tutorial. Just thinking about that person talking is making me yawn.\n\nOne more thing, I keep encountering a rather amusing glitch. Every time I start the game up, it pops up an error warning about my monitor resolution, but the resolution it lists is for my secondary monitor. After I close the error box, the game boots up, anyway, and on the correct monitor. It’s almost like the error message exists in it’s own little world, separate from the game’s actual start-up sequence.

reviewText:
Until recently I would've recommended this game. It's somewhat better than Fallen Enchantress, it was quite a lot better than  Sorcerer King. Great sandbox game, 4x game, tactical combat and rpg (nurse your troups, build your heroes).

Unfortunately Stardock decided to fiddle with it and  they broke it. Half the  time you can no longer see territory, the tactical combat has not been improved as intended, but made annoying and  opened to exploits, and as I found out the hard way, city defense is very broken now - you station an army in a town and they don't get to defend it any longer.

Until those issues are fixed, I can no longer recommend this game at all. Some folk seem to cheer change for the sakes of the NEW, but in this case I do not agree with them at all.

reviewText:
What Heroes of Mights and Magic IV, V and VI should have been.

This game is a great merging of Heroes of Might and Magic III and Masters of Magic, two of the greatest games ever made in turn-based strategy.

FE-LH is an addictive highly replayable game, where you can not only create your hero, but also his race or culture before even beginning to play the actual game.

I think that FE-LH and Crusader Kings 1 and 2 are among the best games that came out since the year 2000, in all game categories. It is fun, chalenging, you can adjust difficulty level of the game, highly customizable game sessions (excellent tweaks you can do before creating a new game), decent amount of items for your heroes, decent amount of troops and monsters you can recruit, and so on.

I highly recommend getting this game. One of the rare games that are worth playing again and again, as well as paying 50$ or less to get.

Thumbs up to the designers!

reviewText:
It's not often wonderful game like this comes around.

It started with how most games end really - an unmitigated disaster in Elemental: War of Magic.

After that release they have pushed hard, reworked, listened, redesigned, and created many new things.

What we have in the end is a PEACH of a game.  It's got a real addicting draw that seems to hold sway longer than a Age of Wonders and Warlock.  It's not 'Hex' based, but don't let that fool you to think it lacks in the tactical department, it's got some fantastic systems and plays very nicely - and not to mention, much quicker, making it more enticing not to let the auto-play/resolve take over.

It's got a lot of depth too, with a very challenging AI especially in the early - mide game, a very well put together set of RPG elements.

In a way, it reminds me of Warlords 3 - Reign of Heroes, which is no small compliment.  It just seems to have just the right mix of RPG and Stategy and also combat and management systems.

Recommended.

reviewText: This game is a blast to play.  It has all the depth that I expect from a Stardock game, yet it isn't unmanageable.  My one complaint is how many times it has crashed on me so far; however, I blame that on my not-quite-up-to-par laptop.  The gameplay is enjoyable and there are many options within the game to help you manage your units and cities without feeling forced to direct EVERY unit.  The quests add great rewards and more things to do than just build and destroy.  The random events, which I did so enjoy in Gal Civ II, add many playback options.  You can craft your own world with its own story, heroes, and lore.  Really, you will get as much out of this game as you're willing to put into it.  I highly recommend this game!

reviewText: A fairly standard turn-based strategy game with a fantasy flavor and tons of customization options. It can be a little buggy at times and the balance seems a little questionable in certain areas, but these issues aren't enough to disqualify it entirely. While I prefer Civ 5 when I'm in the mood for serious gaming, Fallen Enchantress offers enough variety in hero development, quests, and army building to continuously confront me with new and interesting challenges.

reviewText: UPDATED: Fallen Enchantress is a solid game, coming in at around 7.5/10 for me. The fantasy setting infused with magic can be a nice change of pace from the more reality based Civ5. The hero leveling, upgrade, and equipment mechanics are very nice. The devlop stories over time, complete with scars and injuries for defeats in battle. The city system isn't as flexible as Civ5, but is more tailored. While you can only build cities in select locations, each city can be customized from the start. first selecting the focus of the city, then the structures and wonders" built. The multipul win conditions is a standard in 4x nowadays
date: but the victory conditions here are a little more satisfying.\n\nIt is slightly buggy
recommended: but not game breakingly so. The menus and UI need more polish. The overall gameplay can get a little stale sometimes(IMO).\n\nThe battles are a little more hands on with a turn based
hoursPlayed:
grid battleground. I enjoy this more than just stacks of numbers duking it out on a world map. There is an auto-resolve option if you don't want to. It is what it is. You like it or you don't.

reviewText: Fun game for those who like games such as Age of Wonders series and Civi series.  The game is mostly like Age of Wonders especially considering that you have a hero/champion to lead each army you create, however, it is also like Civilzation with the aspects of occupying parts of the map as your cities grow.  Another aspect I like is the world monsters such as dragons, I think that is pretty awesome compared to fighting with simple bandits.  It also uses a similar combat system to that of Age of Wonders 3 which requires you to fight in a tactical grid like movement and turns, think Heroes of Might & Magic in this aspect.\nAll in all its a fun game and if you like the ones I mentioned you should certainly pick this one up too, if you haven't played them I recommend those also.

reviewText: Wonderful game, one of the best TBS games in the genre. Have never had a problem with gameplay such as crashes or problems of that nature. The deep upgrade mechanics and especially the ability to create your own factions and unit in game, that then becomes part of your game to play with as you wish it one of most interesting features of any I've ever played (And since this is my fav genre that means a lot). I will admit that I wont buy any of Stardocks newer titles due to their incorperation of a 34rd party drm, I guess they think they have on the same level as EA and Ubisoft which is NOT an example I would want to follow if they have any sense. Whther they believe it or not, they will lose a lot of sales in  jumping on that bandwagon (A wagon most companies have abandoned due to the reporcussions, as most gamers just are not going to put up with it). Still, THIS game does not incorporate that crap so you are in the clear from that crap. As to the price, this is way too much for ANY game imo, but if ya got the money go for it. If not, wait for a sale of any kind. 20@ or under and it's worth it....the DLC likewise is worth it for the partifular game, so many games have dlc that don't do much, the DLC in this game does add enough to justify buying it.  Over all one of the best games of this genre/atmosphere.

reviewText:
I played this game when it first came out. It was buggy but it had a lot of potential. I decided to put it aside for a bit to give them time to fix some of the issues and add content. If you are a fanboy or part of the dev team you will likely disagree with me, but these are my opinions.

The Good:
-- A lot more content
-- You can customize your hero
-- Create and design your own troops

The Bad:
-- Gold is not hard to come by but shop prices would bankrupt Saudi Arabia
-- When your heroes drop in combat but you win the battle, they are injured. Shops are incredibly hard to come by, the potions, found in shops, to heal your heroes are soo expensive it's better to kill all but 1 of your heroes and use disposable troops. Currently I have 5 heroes, 3 of them have at least 8 injuries, can't be healed.
-- Sometimes when you attack a known force they are orders of magnitude more difficult than expected, for no reason, so sometimes when it should be an easy battle you will get wiped and you are not sure why.
-- Sometimes when you pick up a quest it will have hidden defenders, and you are wiped. See above.
-- Movement is tedious, slow, seems to be done deliberately just to slow down the game.
-- The game play is very slow, over 700 turns to study a new magic skill, really ?!?!?

The Ugly:
-- Bugs. not just in gameplay but also in concept.

It's frustrating because the game is there, they just ruined it with poor decisions.

reviewText: This game is rad.  It very much reminds me of an old game from 1997 called Lords of Magic, with your sovereign and champions exploring the map, sending out scouts to patrol the map, and even improves on the idea by actually allowing you to create your own Sovereign, and even create entirely new civilizations and races for your new characters, and using Pioneers to set up outposts that can build everything from mines to corals around wild animals so you can claim them for your own.  Since I got this game I've been playing it for several days straight and I just love it.

reviewText: I have been playing strategy games since i was like three or four (yes this is a fact my first and probably one of my favorites for a billion reasons is Army Men RTS which I had on the PS2 way back when) and I know a good strategy game when I play one. I love the combat system because unlike the civ games its not really random so you do not have to worry about units that have a stupid amount of defense being killed by some stone age guys with clubs. The only time I have had difficulty with that kind of thing is when I am fighting dragons because they are stupidly powerful(unless its yours then the super powerful thing is not a problem). So if you like civ or other 4x strategy games you will love this.

reviewText:
Edit 2/22:

Having won my first game, I can definately say that the tactical battle system is very good. It's imporved upon, but I'm still somewhat iffy about the use of ranged fighters. Not only can a ranged fighter fling thier projectile clear across the battlefield, but obstructions mean nothing. A company of archer types can launch their volly though what should be completely solid objects. So there is no hiding from these units in the sense of using the environment.

I'm on the fence about how fame is used as a gate mechanic for heroes, especially since it's very possible to blow though those gates and get high leveled heroes while your sovereign is either struggling in a remote location, or sitting in a city, busy in the administer role. While the old mechanic did make acquiring heroes a little easier and a lot more frequent, the heroes that you would run into weren't uber-powered without good reason.

Something I find bothersome is the water, and that's somewhat a two-fold issue. The first part is that water, aside from rivers and swamps, are untraversable. There is no naval mechanic in the game as it stands. This leads to the second issue; the map. While the game has a basic grid, a hex system leads to more naturally shapped coastline. This means your land looks less boxy when looking at maps. But the major problem with the map is that no matter what, the map is all one continet or a group of subcontinets. Islands don't exist. This means that you will inevitablly come into contact with every rival faction if you haven't been killed already. It's not a case of *IF* as much as *WHEN*.

I do like the political parts of the game. The AI isn't as stingy and stupid as it has been in other similar games. If the AI considers you a threat and it has no real way to stand up to you, that dominion will more than likely make contact with you and offer tribute. But sometimes the AI likes to brag about it's research in the most inappropriate ways. Having about 3/4ths of my tech trees completed, one dominion bragged about how it was reclaiming the ancient teachings of archery. I felt like this would be like North Korea bragging to Japan how awesome it is that they have computers that can now use 3.5in floppy disks. I sighed and ignored them, hellbent on fulfilling the requirements for the Spell of Making.

--

Edit 2/21:

After about three hours of fiddling around with files and discovering that the prefs.ini file was not being acquired though the Steam client, I got to play the game as it was intended. As such, this is my honest review.

TBS and 4x are a nice combination and I rather enjoy it. However, I think others might have some problems, I know I still kind of do. The AI is crazy difficult, so if you want a truly easy game to understand how to play, you need to set the difficulty to NOVICE, especially if this is your first time playing.

I enjoy building armies of custom units, upgrading them accordingly, and rteaching heroes abilities to make them better in my conquests, but the game might get a little slowed with the citybuilding aspect. It can take a while to get a city going, and you really need to know the order in which you shoudl construct buildings before you really get into the nitty-gritty of the game.

Combat is both fun and challenging at the same time. The challenge comes from the initiative feature, so it's important to pay close attention to your initiative bar before really doing anything foolish. So you really need to put consideration into timing, building and upgrading units and understanding the mechanics of battle.

The storyline is pretty non-existant. The Cataclysm happened and the races are all scrambling about trying to get re-established as dominions. There are two side, Kingdom and Empire and to say either is a good guy or bad guy remains to be seen. It can be rather relative in this game. However being aligned with either of these two superfactions" makes negotiations with the opposing "superfactions" a little more difficult because of an inherent mistrust. And just because you;re aligned with one dosen;t mean the other factions will be nice and leave you alone. No
recommended: they will smell the blood in the water and crush you just as well as the other side would.\n\nSo with this said
hoursPlayed: after the hours long struggle to actually get this game to work
voteText: it's really not a bad game. It might be slow for some
helpfulPercent:
but it has a ncie balance of elements that makes it fairly challenging and fun.

--

reviewText:
It feels and plays a lot like Civilization with a quest and individual hero system built in.

The combat can be automatic outside of quests, like Civilization, or you can choose to battle turn-based style on a grid map (which I suck at in this game).

The questing system is unique with this kind of game, and I really enjoy it. I played on easy and felt that the pacing was a little to fast as far as difficulty advancement, but this didn't hinder how fun it was. The quests have stories to go along that may involve getting new equipment, general, or army guys, which makes questing very worth it.

I don't really like the tutorials, but as someone who still hasn't done it, I really suggest doing it. I can't seem to figure out how to get guild points" as they don't seem to act the same as in Civilization even though it looks like it came from that game. There are little differences that if you have played or haven't played Civilization
date: it really makes the tutorial quite appealing.\n\nI was disappointed to have so many characters and only about three (way less than half; not even a quarter) were female. However
recommended: the female characters that were there had great backgrounds and characters
hoursPlayed: unlike other games where females are token characters / boring sex symbols.\n\nThere is no customization except for naming stuff
voteText: and the buildings are automatically placed in order that you choose to build them."

reviewText:
Edit 2/22:

Having won my first game, I can definately say that the tactical battle system is very good. It's imporved upon, but I'm still somewhat iffy about the use of ranged fighters. Not only can a ranged fighter fling thier projectile clear across the battlefield, but obstructions mean nothing. A company of archer types can launch their volly though what should be completely solid objects. So there is no hiding from these units in the sense of using the environment.

I'm on the fence about how fame is used as a gate mechanic for heroes, especially since it's very possible to blow though those gates and get high leveled heroes while your sovereign is either struggling in a remote location, or sitting in a city, busy in the administer role. While the old mechanic did make acquiring heroes a little easier and a lot more frequent, the heroes that you would run into weren't uber-powered without good reason.

Something I find bothersome is the water, and that's somewhat a two-fold issue. The first part is that water, aside from rivers and swamps, are untraversable. There is no naval mechanic in the game as it stands. This leads to the second issue; the map. While the game has a basic grid, a hex system leads to more naturally shapped coastline. This means your land looks less boxy when looking at maps. But the major problem with the map is that no matter what, the map is all one continet or a group of subcontinets. Islands don't exist. This means that you will inevitablly come into contact with every rival faction if you haven't been killed already. It's not a case of *IF* as much as *WHEN*.

I do like the political parts of the game. The AI isn't as stingy and stupid as it has been in other similar games. If the AI considers you a threat and it has no real way to stand up to you, that dominion will more than likely make contact with you and offer tribute. But sometimes the AI likes to brag about it's research in the most inappropriate ways. Having about 3/4ths of my tech trees completed, one dominion bragged about how it was reclaiming the ancient teachings of archery. I felt like this would be like North Korea bragging to Japan how awesome it is that they have computers that can now use 3.5in floppy disks. I sighed and ignored them, hellbent on fulfilling the requirements for the Spell of Making.

--

Edit 2/21:

After about three hours of fiddling around with files and discovering that the prefs.ini file was not being acquired though the Steam client, I got to play the game as it was intended. As such, this is my honest review.

TBS and 4x are a nice combination and I rather enjoy it. However, I think others might have some problems, I know I still kind of do. The AI is crazy difficult, so if you want a truly easy game to understand how to play, you need to set the difficulty to NOVICE, especially if this is your first time playing.

I enjoy building armies of custom units, upgrading them accordingly, and rteaching heroes abilities to make them better in my conquests, but the game might get a little slowed with the citybuilding aspect. It can take a while to get a city going, and you really need to know the order in which you shoudl construct buildings before you really get into the nitty-gritty of the game.

Combat is both fun and challenging at the same time. The challenge comes from the initiative feature, so it's important to pay close attention to your initiative bar before really doing anything foolish. So you really need to put consideration into timing, building and upgrading units and understanding the mechanics of battle.

The storyline is pretty non-existant. The Cataclysm happened and the races are all scrambling about trying to get re-established as dominions. There are two side, Kingdom and Empire and to say either is a good guy or bad guy remains to be seen. It can be rather relative in this game. However being aligned with either of these two superfactions" makes negotiations with the opposing "superfactions" a little more difficult because of an inherent mistrust. And just because you;re aligned with one dosen;t mean the other factions will be nice and leave you alone. No
recommended: they will smell the blood in the water and crush you just as well as the other side would.\n\nSo with this said
hoursPlayed: after the hours long struggle to actually get this game to work
voteText: it's really not a bad game. It might be slow for some
helpfulPercent:
but it has a ncie balance of elements that makes it fairly challenging and fun.

--

reviewText: At first impression Fallen Enchantress is, for all intents and purposes, a fantasy-flavored Sid Meier's Civilization V clone. If you enjoyed Sid Meier's Civilization V and you enjoy fantasy elements in games you may well enjoy Fallen Enchantress. If you did not enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization V, or have not played Sid Meier's Civilization V because it didn't look like your kind of thing, or do not enjoy fantasy elements in games, you will probably not enjoy Fallen Enchantress. Personally, I did not enjoy Sid Meier's Civilization V and as such I proceeded not to enjoy Fallen Enchantress for much the same reasons.

reviewText: I am simply dumbfounded by the positive reviews for this game.  This game is an ongoing tragedy in what not to do as a game developer.  From the very beginning (in its first incarnation as Elemental: War of Magic) this game was doomed to failure.  From its horrid UI, to it's uninspired gameplay, vintage 1990's graphics, and abysmal balance--the game plays more like a college student's unfinished Unity 3D project than anything else.  How it has garnered fans of any kind is beyond me.\n\nI've always enjoyed games such as: Master of Magic, Disciples, Heroes of Might and Magic, and Age of Wonders, so, as a longtime supporter of Stardock/Bred Wardell, I was looking forward to their foray into the realm of Fantasy 4x.  One word sums up my experience:  Disappointment.  For the life of me, I don't understand how a game developer that produced Galactic Civilizations could produce something so unpolished and uninspired like Elemental/Fallen Enchantress.  It's like they didn't even research the genre--they just looked at Master of Magic and said, Well
date: we can do better than that!".  The only problem with that point of view is that other/better developers had already made better fantasy 4x games
recommended: and had been pushing the genre forward for nearly a decade.\n\nFallen Enchantress is a failed attempt at saving an aborted development project
hoursPlayed: nothing more.  A new development director was hired to rework the UI and add (i.e.
voteText: "tack on") some new features--things like distict races
helpfulPercent: unique abilites
votesHelpful: etc.--things that should have already been part of the initial design--in a desperate attempt to save an already-doomed game.  For some people
votesTotal: this was enough.  Gamers unfamiliar with the fantasy 4x genre liked what they saw
votesFunny: while veterans of the genre just asked the question:  "Why?  Why try to save this game?  Just let it go already."\n\nThere are no bright spots with this game--not when you look around at all of the other
commentsCount: better fantasy 4x games that are out there.  As already mentioned

column20: this game game out in the 2010+ era of PC games
column23: PC gamers deserve better than this lukewarm dalliance with hubris.\n\nAlso

reviewText: Of all my adventure games, this is by far my favorite. I love the graphics and gameplay. But I mostly like the scope. In my opinion, Endless Legend gets far too much hype. THIS is the game that inspired that one and others that came afterwards. The UI may be a bit rough around the edges but that's small potatoes compared to the game's engine. You have stacks of stuff to see, quest to pursue, and enemies to engage. I've never seen a game with so many different foes and characters save Age of Wonders III and the Warlock series. You can play the campaigns and have a wonderful time. But if you play a random map with random enemies and random other stuff, you're in for a real treat. Make sure to add all the DLCs.

reviewText:
Having played this it's pretty dissappointing. It just appears to be a lightly modified and improved version of the last Fallen Enchantress game, unlike the really awesome Endless Legend which has a lot more variety and feel to it. I find that even with the enemy AI being set to easy that they are still a great pain in the ♥♥♥.

The major improvement they have done with this game is made it so that heroes level up in more complex and interesting ways which works well when you make your own kind of hero, however it doesn't excuse being a seporate game from the origonal, in my opinion.

It'd be worth it on a sale as the game itself is rarther fun and great for anyone looking for a fun 4X game, but I'd stick with Endless Legend instead, which has it's own interesting story unfold too.

reviewText:
Really disappointing.  I would not recommend this game.

The gameplay is dull and uninspired, the unit creation is overcomplicated, unit variety is mostly indistinguishable.

There are also a host of thematic issues that made playing the game a chore, such as the fog of war being far too dark, and undiscovered regions being black.  In Civilization 5 they use a sort of grey cloudcover to hide unexplored regions, which means that most of the pixels on your screen are bright, but the flat black of Fallen Enchantress casts the entire game in a gloomy light, leaving the whole experience feeling hollow.

I wanted to like the game, but when I got the last card I realised how that was the only reason I was continuing to play it.  Just don't bother, there are better games available.

reviewText:
This game would be very awesome if not for a crippling bug.  You use outposts to control land area in the game.  However, if an enemy captures an outpost and you re-capture it, the zone of control will be smaller.  If this happens multiple times, the zone of control will be non-existent.  This bug has been in the game since before the expansion came out.  I stopped playing the first time because of the bug, and I've now uninstalled the game and given up on it because the developers don't seem to care about fixing it.

Now, you can just destroy the outpost and rebuild it, but that also means rebuilding all of the addons associated with the outpost, which can get horribly time consuming.

If the developer ever gets around to fixing this bug, let me know.  The game would be quite fun if not for that fatal flaw which leads to much frustration.

reviewText:
Boring game.  I dont particularly like Civilization type games but I played Civ5 for 20hrs+  but this game is really boring compared to Civ5, even though I like RPG stuff that Civ5 dont really have... so gameplay is really boring to even spoil that one.  I like turn based games in particular I dont really know why this game is so lousy.

Maybe it is the design elements.  The castle building screen is so lousy.  The immersion is lousy.  I guess everything in this game is lousy.  The battles are lousy.  The graphics in the battle is so lousy that I cant understand an old game like Kings Bounty have a better battle screen than this.  And I wanted to really like this game too.

I suggest a better game - Eador - Masters of the Broken World.   Many complain because of bugs but its more of the first players that played that game.  But that game rocks and many people who actually complained are playing it for 200-400 hrs+.  Some even for 1000+ hrs.  So that game is worth every cent.  I cant review it here because I got it from GOG, so I just review it here in Fallen Enchantress coz I paid for this game hoping I may find another gem like Eador.. but it failed miserably.

TLDR: Nice Game for those who like Strategy and pretending they are incharge of an Area and if skilled enough, make allies, enemies, Declare War...Propose Treaties, gain fame and even a pet C:

Let's start this of quickly...Tried it for the  free weekend and it is an AMAZING game. ( Granted i spent like 3 hours preparing only to wrecked cause i couldn't save enough Glidar and Mass produce my Armies cause i suck and Game over for me )

With that being said...You MUST have a great knowledge about this game to understand what your doing ( I thought i was MLG  and skipped the tutorial only to just sit there and click around asking where is my MP7 :C..COD joke w/e.)

I did the tutorial and it was more simple then i was OK I GOT THIS. After a few mins of customization ( prob like 30-45 Mins due to all the options ) I picked the Map layout ( even more options ) and enemies  ( Even MORE options ) or Allies ( depends how you treat them )

In Game; Fast Paced and A Quick Thinker to know what your doing indeed. As i was playing i didn't know what to do but after like 2 Hours...i started understanding it BUT THEM BOOM i got declared war on T.T and Game Over.

Main Point: Make a Character...Settle on a land, Research and Build Cities and then repeat Research and Cities.

THE BAD- There were some annoyances to me as i never played games like this for NEW players who don't have the understanding of a game today will call it repetitive as the only thing you is Research and Build Cities and Do Quest.

Other then that nice game over all... btw Small Map = 9/10 IGN To Much Water
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
BLUF: The game isn't worth $30, I paid a total of $14 for Elemental (the first one), and FE:LH (this one) - I'm a sales hunter. I have no misgivings, FE:LH (this one) has everything in it that Elemental did. So, if you're going to buy one, skip to this one.




Detail:
So, I enjoy modding this game. I'm going to say that right up front... so let me break this into two separate sections, vanilla and not.

Vanilla:
It's a passable strategy game with elements of RPG but not enough to call it an RPG game. Don't come in expecting Civ because that's stupid. Aside from the developers, I see nobody saying anything about Civ in relation to the game except in reviews from people saying its not like Civ (which they expected due to Devs who worked in ome way on Civ).

The game play is pretty straight forward - make units, fight on a tactical grid-map. Use Block to reduce damage from hits, Dodge to avoid hits (even ranged), and spell resist to avoid magic or damage from magic. The built in options to customize a faction, a hero (sovereign), and your own units lend replability to the game. The AI will use created factions as minor races" if you aren't using them in a scenario. Always nice.

While this is billed as a the Fallen Enchantress come to enslave the world
date: thats really not it at all. There is a minor campaign that took a tops of 3 hours to complete (and only that cause I like to wander). That dealt with the enchantress
hoursPlayed:
she was one of the easiest to beat factions. The game is really about random scenarios against random (or selected) factions including your custom ones.

It IS buggy in some annoying spots:
-  Basically anywhere that you enter text runs into issues (such as custom facions backstory and custom Hero Backstory).
-  Custom maps have issues erasing each other in the cartographer tool
-  Altering generated maps in the Cartographer Tool will sometimes cause creatures to spawn on ocen-cliff tiles and make them unkillable outside of magic
-  You can only kill the Vanilla "Ridiculous" difficulty setting (well all of them) aren't vastly different from the normal in my experience.
-  It crashes infrequently
voteText:
but the autosave feature makes it only a mildly annoying issue (for me).

Modded:

The scripting is pretty easy and straight forward. You can even port in 3D models if you're so inclined. The game was intended for modding but isn't set up for the Steam community. In fact
helpfulPercent: I doubt its even set up for Stardock (not that I've ever been there). I use NEXUS forums if I hit a roadblock or want to see what others have done.\nYou can even alter the AI behavior to make the game more challenging
votesHelpful: nerf ranged attacks if that's your piece
votesTotal: or do as some folks did and overhaul the game. Or
votesFunny: if you're lazy
commentsCount: download their versions and have the game overhauled for you.\nAlso
column16: you can add in items or nerf existing ones if you feel the game is all about who has the bigger stick.\n\n- Some folks have claimed to fix the above vanilla bugs
column17: I haven't experienced that.\n\n"
column18: January 25, 2015
column19: true

reviewText:
tl:dr: good mechanics, interesting spells, poor AI and shallow tech tree. Fun to play.

The best thing is that you can create your own troops by choosing their traits and equipment. Too bad that game is balanced so that your only option is to pile up as many magical items on your troops as possible and thus eliminate the power of choise whenever to supply many troops with poor equipment or few troops with expensive equipment.

In the endgame spells are a bit too powerful. Since there isn't any multiplay, the developers haven't bothered to tune down some cataclysm spells like Volcano, which can eradicate whole cities in few turns and alter the environment so that AI has no clue how to cope with that.

reviewText: while I do recommend this game I have a few things to note about. It has a few fairly noticable bugs. like I had to avoid the tutorials because they made my screen black out entirely. And the user interface I felt was terrible and horribly scattered. I also wish that building custom stuff was simpler but eh. get past that and the character customization was decent and the abilities on leveling were okay. It wasn't that fast paced and the research tree was a little gawdy. But the fantasy appeal of Dragons, epic weapons, epic creatures and crushing cities to dust kept me hanging on. overall I would say 5/10. I would play one whole game. But it's hard to get past critical design flaws and ugly UI.

reviewText:
Civilization and Age of Wonders had a baby? I think so. It would be heresy to compare it to Masters of Magic though...

The unit customizer is one of my favorite feature. Sometimes its to make best use of your materials available and sometimes its just to be a bit silly. In one game i had a severe shortage of metal, but plentiful crystal and horses. What was the end result of this you say? Why obviously club wielding knights with wizard robes and enchanted cloaks.

I've spent countless hours playing this game because there is just so much to explore. If you are a RPG fan and enjoy Grandscale Turn-based strategy games, this one is a must buy.

reviewText:
Most of the Elemental (notice they don't even use that name anymore) games could be measured in varying degrees of complete and ugly abortions.  To be fair, the developers have given me the last few games of this series for free just because the first iteration was such a complete damn mess.

This is the first time I feel they really got it right.  Customization is cool, AI isn't completely nonsensical, graphics have a cool style.  Even long games stay fairly interesting and there is almost always an area you can just barely survive in or mobs/creeps/whatever that is just enough of a challenge.

Totally worth your time and money this time around if you are a fan of the Age of Wonders or Heroes of Might and Magic type genre.  If you are not, we are not friends.  Sorry if you are just finding this out now  :(

reviewText:
A game that combines two of my favorite genres in gaming? Oh my. This game takes what was once known as Elemental: War of Magic and turns it into a game that truely is worthy of the Stardock label. This game so effortlessly combines the roles of empire making games with Dungeons and Dragons style heroic adventures you would be hard pressed to find a match for this game at any point in the history of video games. The graphics while not the most realistic are equally astounding in their artistic flavor, walls look imposing even from the god pov you are in for the entirety of the game. For instance my capital of Iphidar is surrounded by walls that put the walls of Constantinople to shame.

The integration of magic in this game is so well done as to be second nature within five minutes of starting the game, casting city wide spells to boost productivity or city wide curses on your enemies to make their own citizens fight them has never been so easy or satisfying. Magic is litterally everywhere game. The world has stones littered through out it that act as focal points for magic and allow you to cast spels of greater potency or boost your already existing spells.

Let us mot forget this is an empire building game as well. The governmental aspects of the game are what I have come to expect froma Stardock 4x game. They are in a word amazing. Extremely user friendly while allowing the player to govern all things a real government does i.e. taxes, building, army raising, ect. The interaction between in game states is simply amazing, the ai programmed for this game so realistically reacts to the players actions I am sometimes hard pressed to not believe there is another person controlling them.

My opinion of this game is very high and am glad Stardock was able to rectify the utter disaster that was Elemental with this game and its predecessor Fallen Enchantress. I highly reccomend this game to all lovers of tactical planning and nation building and who have the patience to deal with the pace of turn based games.

reviewText:
In my book, this game runs a very close second to Disciples 2 - right up until we start talking about the custom factions, unit designer, and all the other design tools built in. I haven't had the time or patience to monkey with anything besides the Cartographer's Table (Map Editor), but holy Notice of Termination Batman, this thing let's you desing your own spell effects, and map tiles.

If you're a slightly more casual player like moi, you may be content to unfairly stack the deck (map) in your favor, design your own faction and then design a mounted company unit called Fist of the Empress, subsequently mass producing them. Because the computer will still slap you around, that's why.

11/10

P.S. You can recruit Dragons into your army.

reviewText: From the makers of the galactic civilizations games, this turned-based strategy game is basically the same type of game with a swords and sorcery theme imposed on it.  Instead of creating spaceships, you create train and/or breed different miliary units, train distinctive heroes, etc.  The basic premise of exploration + research + conquest remains the same, however.\n\nThe game has some baggage that comes with it from an earlier buugy release.  I missed out on all of that, picking it up after the bugs had been resolved.  My experience was solid and bug-free... though the winning solution did seem more apparent than with either of the GalCiv games.

Its not the best 4x but it definitely has its charm and worth playing. The game is full of great ideas mostly underdeveloped but still done well enough that it doesn’t take away from the experience.

I hope to see another instalment of this game with a little more refinement in the future.

reviewText:
Awesome design, awesome game, but not 10/10.

First problem is ui, optimization and not-intuitive controls.
Second problem is a lot of bugs in gameplay.
Third problem is tutorial, which helps you to learn how to move mouse, but not how to understand the game mechanics
And no campaign is my personal fourth problem

Otherwise it has a lot of good sides
Variative heroes and RPG unit system is much more adorable than in Civ5 or in Warlock 1. You can equip every single unit, you can build a mage with sword and chainmail, you can earn legendary artifacts with variable effects and stats.
Tactical and strategical figths, magic and solves. It looks like mix of Disciples2 tactical map and civ3 strategical map
DRAGONS!!!11111
Mighty quests for epic loots, solve different quests such as kill rats in the house or summon the great fallen dragon to chat.

Totally worth it's cost for every 4x antasy strategy fans, but too expensive without any special offer for others.

My point is 8 out of 10

reviewText:
Recommended for fans of TBS strategy and 4x games.  It plays similar to a cross between Civilization and Heroes of Might and Magic.  It is imperfect but may be the best fantasy 4x game out within the last few years.  Pros and cons listed in DETAIL below if you find them helpful.

Pros:
-Fun gameplay.  It delivers a quality 4x experience.
-Intuitive mechanics.  If you have played 4x games, you will grasp this game's concepts quickly.
-Good tactical combat.  You can make a difference if you take command versus just autoresolve everything.  Tactical combat is not as strong as Heroes of Might and Magic or Age of Wonders 3, but it is a fun and useful part of the game.
-Tame the land mechanic".  There are plenty of neutral monsters and quests to make expansion more than an uninteresting early-game land grab.
-Satisfying empire building.  Your cities level just like your heroes
date: and there are a variety of customizations options for each city.  This is a great mechanic!  Yet city management is streamlined enought that you don't get too bogged down late game with many cities.\n-Custom units.  You can make your own custom military units with their own characteristics once you've gotten the appropriate research and resoruces.  While more customization options would be nice
recommended: it is a very cool and welcome mechanic.\n-Minimal waiting in between turns (in contrast to the long waits in Civilization 5).  The AI is thinking about its turn when you are taking yours
hoursPlayed:
so the time it takes to execute their turn is minimal.  This is a big plus.

Cons:
-Graphics are ugly.  I suppose on the spectrum of 4x graphics
voteText: it is somewhere in the middle (with Dominions being ugliest and Civilization/Heroes of Might and Magic/ Age of Wonders 3 being pretty).\n-Spells are bland and there are not enough of them.  I was never excited to get access to a new spell.  Spell research is also somewhat confusing - you get spells through a confusing combination of leveling your heroes and through research.  Master of Magic got spells exactly right and I wish more modern games would simply copy and improve on their model.  In MoM
helpfulPercent: you could make your own towns a paradise (all with nice little spell effects)
votesHelpful: you could summon awesome units
votesTotal: you could blight an enemy town with pestilence
votesFunny: chaos rifts
commentsCount: etc (all visualized nicely)
column16: you could plunge the world into eternal night
column17: and you simply researched each spell individually and intuitively.  FE has fewer and less exciting options.\n-Hero advancement is similarly bland.  Although there was an extensive list of traits to acquire
column18: I was never excited to gain a new level with my hero because none of the traits were that interesting.  Contrast this to the excellent system in the Heroes of Might and Magic series.  In that series
column19: getting Grandmaster Fire Mage or even Basic Logistics was always exciting because the skills were useful and interesting.  This is not so in FE sadly.\n-Not enough fantasy creatures on your side.  You may get about 3 uninteresting summoning spells (only 1 of which is good) that are limited to 1 summoned creature per spell per hero.  So you will not lead a shambling horde of zombies and skeletons or demons like you could in Master of Magic or Dominions.  A few races also have access to 1 fantasy creature that they can recruit directly from towns (and you can even customize
column20: which is cool but really limited).  If you capture the right location on the map or complete a long questline
column21: you may get a dragon (one) as well.  Humanoid troops are nice fodder and need to be there
column22: but they should be 60-70% of your army
column23: not 98% of it.  The reason people want to play this type of game instead of Civilization is specifically FOR the fantasy creatures and the spells!\n-Races are bland.  For some reason
column24: Stardock departed from fantasy conventions of men
column29: they have races that are elf-like and dwarf-like and orc-like
column30: but they are  more humanoid and less interesting.  Except for a few structures and traits
column31: they all play similarly.  Again I must compare to Master of Magic where each race had its own unique units and tech tree.  Also compare to HoMM 3 or 5 - each race felt unique and played differently.\n-Weak
column32: uninteresting quest items.  In spite of a lot of questing
column33: I seemed to only get bland
column35: and uninteresting reward items.  I would always replace them from the shop whenever I researched the right tech.\n-Furthermore
column36: there is no mechanic to make your own powerful items.  Master of Magic
column38: and to a lesser extent Age of Wonders all got this right.  I should be able to expend considerable magic resources to make a great artifact for my heroes to use.  Whether that's a sword that raises  slain foes as zombie minions
column39: armor that makes the wearer ethereal
column40: a horn that empowers the troops
column41: or a staff that disintegrates the enemy
column42: this mechanic is sorely missing in FE.\n-There is little penalty for heroes defeated in combat.  They simply get a tiny permanent debuff (typically of little to no consequence) and respawn the next turn at low health in your nearest town.  While there should be some mechanism to retrieve your fallen sovereign or save your heroes with extraordinary magic
column43: I personally prefer both my heroes and my enemy's heroes to die and stay dead under most circumstances.  Heck
column44: in Dominions not only did dead characters stay dead (albiet with the possibility of resurrection or magical unlife)
column45: they could get significant battle wounds even if they survived victorious combat.  In Heroes of Might and Magic
column46: the defeated hero would abandon your cause entirely.\n-Poor optimization.  The game chugged on my old computer to the point of unplayability mid-game.  It still gets a little chunky on my new Alienware hotrod.  For a game with such primitive 3D graphics

that should not happen!

Conclusion:  Recommended to fans of the genre
This game is a good

reviewText: This game has a great concept. Despite its mid-90s graphics, the mix of strategy and RPG, the way you can customize your heroes and your units, the interesting quests and monsters - all of that is timeless and shines in spite of the graphics.\n\nHOWEVER - I cannot recommend this game because of how incredibly buggy and poorly polished it is. This game takes more RAM and CPU resources than games far more technologically advanced (i.e. Civ 5, XCOM, Endless Space). It crashes every 3-5 turns. It often freezes during a battle, and reloading a prior save doesn't help. Lastly, reloading saves reliably crashes the game on my computer, and again, I run far more advanced games than this with no problems. I've asked the developer for support and troubleshooting and it never helped. Unlike other games that started out buggy but was fixed and smoothed with patches (i.e. Divinity Original Sin), this game has essentially been abandoned by its developers and I have not seen any fixes for years. What could have been a great game has been ruined by bugs.

reviewText:
I got this game for 10$ cad on sale, and for that price it no doubt good.  The game does get repetitive and the AI is not good at all.  You can simply turtle through the game even on the 2nd highest difficulty. I haven't bothered with the highest difficulty yet, but I'm sure it is the same because the AI simply gets more resource boosts.  The devs also seem to have a habit of rehashing their games a lot, this being the 3rd iteration of Elemental.  I have not played Elemental or Fallen Enchantress, but I have read that they are almost the same as FE: Legendary Heroes.

I got this game at 75% so I was not disappointed, at 10$ there is still ample play and it is a good deal, but in the long run I would rather play Master of Magic, which seemed to have a bit more depth and more variety of creatures and magic.

Edit: This game is no where near as good as Age of Wonders III. I will still leave a positive recommendation because I got this game for 10$ on sale, and because they game isn't completely horrible.  The ai  never seems to try and attack and that is the biggest problem with this game.

reviewText:
I am a novice in the 4X genre. I first played a Civilization game (Call to Power) 15 years ago, but haven't explored the genre much since. As such, I cannot confidently speak to if Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes meets/exceeds the expectations of fully initiated fans of games like these, or how it compares to any other benchmark titles in the genre's history. All I can say is that I love this game, and I am definitely going to be looking for more games of this genre.

I love the fantasy medieval styling, and the gameplay (magic mechanics, designing units, outposts, diplomacy, empire-mangement, heroes, quests, etc) are all really interesting.

Can't wait to see more content for this game. Sequels, expansions?

reviewText: I bought Elemental when it first came out and well, it was pretty bad. The one thing good about Elemental was the unique gameplay. It was fun. Fallen Enchatress is no different. The interactivity of research unlocking items that you can put on your troops and heroes so they can be better defended and better armed is really neat. Not to mention the level ups of individual units and the new unit upgrade feature. Mana is much easier to manage in this game because it's just a single, empire wide stat. Also, the choice between the two types of empires and their differences is really quite neat. All in all, this is a great strategy game with a heaping of RPG and the partial city system of civilization but not so complicated. REcommended highly.

reviewText:
A mix of CIV and Heroes of Might and Magic. The maps can be enormous and will take you 20+ hours to complete. There are also smaller maps that, of course, are much less time intensive.

With a mix of empire building, research, resource management (yes, you can run out of iron to build those awesome units, but so can the ai) mixed with RPG leveling of your sovereign and champions, there is a lot you can do.

That said, the pace can be slow. You have options on the customization of creating a world, but I kind of like the slower pace as my units are not obsolete in 10 turns. Research basically allows you to upgrade armor, weapons, etc. of basic units. Not like CIV where you have spearmen, pikemen, etc. They are essentially the same, with different buffs. You can give them fire resitent cloaks, magic necklaces etc. However, it will cost you more in resources. In a strange twist, it is more expensive to buy things for your heroes!

The AI is pretty decent, but not that good at measuring army strengths and weaknesses. This can lead the AI to wasting expensive troops against their counters. Afterwords, you can mop them up as they have little armor.

Overall, it is engaging and does have that one more turn" thing. It deserves an 8 of 10.



"

reviewText: At the discounted price, this game is a golden opportunity, even for those who aren't addicted to 4x games.  You will get more than $10 of value just playing the scenarios and following the storyline, and there are few games that are as replayable.  Wander aimlessly and explore every dark nook (set world creation to lots of monsters and wildlands), or min/max in your drive to conquer the world (decent AI at the higher levels, and these developers have historically been dedicated to improving the sophistication of their games).  Fantasy, role playing, strategy, exploration--there's something in this blend for just about everyone (heh, unless you are dedicated to twitch gaming).

reviewText: This is an excellent combo of empire building and RPG.  I did read previous reviews and I can see the Civ 5 comparison and it is valid, there are similarities with city building & tech trees, but it has the extra dimension of having heroes to find loot, do quests, upgrade weapons, armour and skills and it works brilliantly.  It's not as easy as some reviewers claim (unless you save the game before battles and reload if you lose, which I think takes away the fun) but if you like turn based combat you will love it.  You learn to pick your battles, there are no shortage of heroes so if you lose one its not too bad, they do heal after they 'die' but in the early game it does limit what you can do and you will fall behind your rivals. I do like the fact that, unlike most turn based combat, your armies can have up to 9 units so you have a mix of defensive, ranged and attacking units.  Although set in a Fantasy style world I am avoiding magic (alright I do have a healing spell) and with my second attempt (on default settings) I am  managing to hold my own but not always in the lead. I can see many different ways to win, the maps are randomly generated each time, the difficulty setting is variable, the diplomacy is better than Civ 5 and I am looking forward to many happy hours of game play.   I would recommend a look on YouTube before you buy and if you think you might like it you definately will.  I havent seen a clip yet where they are having as much fun as I am now... 9/10

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A turn-based strategy game that borrows heavily from Civilization and that ilk, this one has some distinctions to set it apart.  Like in Civ you'll manage a growing empire of cities looking to spread across the world, and dominate it via one of several victory conditions.  Unlike with Civ the combat is turn-based tactical where clever use of your stuff will allow a weaker enemy to prevail against a stronger one.  Also the setting is a sort of high fantasy where magic is an important resource, the mastery of which is crucial to the game.

More importantly, Legendary Heroes lives up to its name by giving each side a sovereign, and several lesser champions which gain in power as if in an RPG.  These heroes can be mages, warriors, or generals, with large and varied skill trees to progress along.  It's this last bit that makes this such a fun game: at the start of the game where many of the early turns are about watching your cities grow your heroes can be mucking about, exploring and killing bandits.

A great entry in the 'just one more turn' category of games, Legendary Heroes does right a lot of things its predecessors did wrong.

In my book, this game runs a very close second to Disciples 2 - right up until we start talking about the custom factions, unit designer, and all the other design tools built in. I haven't had the time or patience to monkey with anything besides the Cartographer's Table (Map Editor), but holy Notice of Termination Batman, this thing let's you desing your own spell effects, and map tiles.

If you're a slightly more casual player like moi, you may be content to unfairly stack the deck (map) in your favor, design your own faction and then design a mounted company unit called Fist of the Empress, subsequently mass producing them. Because the computer will still slap you around, that's why.

11/10

P.S. You can recruit Dragons into your army.

reviewText:
UPdate: After playing Warlock 2 and AOW 3 I must say that FA:LH is a better game overall than both of them. HOwever, I really do prefer the tactical combat of AOW3 better and I like the troops of W2 a lot also. It's just that overall FA:LH is a better complete 4x package than both of them.

Great game overall. Really cool units and hero system. More like AOW2 and HM&M than Civ. I really like the limited city building that prevents city spamming.
At times can get a little slow while you are waiting to build up an army and the music does not help this.
Diplomacy is pretty good with what you can do for trades. AI is not too bad.
Biggest complaint is lack of custom maps/good map editor and lack of workshop intergration for new content.
DLC is fairly weak so be careful before you get it.

reviewText: This is the Exp to Fallen Enchantress and in my opinion a needed element to the original game. Not only does it add two new races (Humans: Capitarians-Merchants, Fallen: Urxen- Ind Armies) and a new leveling system for all the heroes, along with more monsters, and magic to cast into the world. For anyone not familiar with Fallen Enchantress, it is a TBS 4x game with generals who level up similar to a RPG system. The strength of your empire and random encounters determine how many heroes you have to help lead your army. Anyone who likes RPG's and city builders, should try Fallen Enchantress, and this DLC will add a lot of richness to the orginal game's experience.

reviewText: This turn-based 4x game is set in a fantasy world.  The player represents a faction leader who grants special abilities to the race he controls.  The leaders have backstories and special attributes which make picking a leader about more than just selecting a color for your tokens.  The real focus of gameplay are the heroes which level up and gain power over the course of the game.  The game is a bit buggy, but I still love it and I've put in over 400 hours so far.  Probably the best comparison would be Master of Magic or Age of Wonders.

reviewText:
A mix of CIV and Heroes of Might and Magic. The maps can be enormous and will take you 20+ hours to complete. There are also smaller maps that, of course, are much less time intensive.

With a mix of empire building, research, resource management (yes, you can run out of iron to build those awesome units, but so can the ai) mixed with RPG leveling of your sovereign and champions, there is a lot you can do.

That said, the pace can be slow. You have options on the customization of creating a world, but I kind of like the slower pace as my units are not obsolete in 10 turns. Research basically allows you to upgrade armor, weapons, etc. of basic units. Not like CIV where you have spearmen, pikemen, etc. They are essentially the same, with different buffs. You can give them fire resitent cloaks, magic necklaces etc. However, it will cost you more in resources. In a strange twist, it is more expensive to buy things for your heroes!

The AI is pretty decent, but not that good at measuring army strengths and weaknesses. This can lead the AI to wasting expensive troops against their counters. Afterwords, you can mop them up as they have little armor.

Overall, it is engaging and does have that one more turn" thing. It deserves an 8 of 10.



"

reviewText: At the discounted price, this game is a golden opportunity, even for those who aren't addicted to 4x games.  You will get more than $10 of value just playing the scenarios and following the storyline, and there are few games that are as replayable.  Wander aimlessly and explore every dark nook (set world creation to lots of monsters and wildlands), or min/max in your drive to conquer the world (decent AI at the higher levels, and these developers have historically been dedicated to improving the sophistication of their games).  Fantasy, role playing, strategy, exploration--there's something in this blend for just about everyone (heh, unless you are dedicated to twitch gaming).

reviewText:
Awesome design, awesome game, but not 10/10.

First problem is ui, optimization and not-intuitive controls.
Second problem is a lot of bugs in gameplay.
Third problem is tutorial, which helps you to learn how to move mouse, but not how to understand the game mechanics
And no campaign is my personal fourth problem

Otherwise it has a lot of good sides
Variative heroes and RPG unit system is much more adorable than in Civ5 or in Warlock 1. You can equip every single unit, you can build a mage with sword and chainmail, you can earn legendary artifacts with variable effects and stats.
Tactical and strategical figths, magic and solves. It looks like mix of Disciples2 tactical map and civ3 strategical map
DRAGONS!!!11111
Mighty quests for epic loots, solve different quests such as kill rats in the house or summon the great fallen dragon to chat.

Totally worth it's cost for every 4x antasy strategy fans, but too expensive without any special offer for others.

My point is 8 out of 10
